[Falco]: What is the plan for when they'll stating the future of Cornell Stadium?

[Falco]: Some of these might be short fixes, but when you walk through and you see that the press box has a hole in the roof, the vinyl sidings falling off the side, I mean, you go outside into the parking lot, the benches are in disrepair.

[Falco]: This is a gateway to our community.

[Falco]: When you think about Hormel Stadium, there are people that are coming in each and every week, because Hormel Stadium is probably busier than it's ever been.

[Falco]: People are coming in from all over the place.

[Falco]: This is a gateway to our community.

[Falco]: So when they see the stadium and they see, in some aspects, the condition it's in, you know, I think they really start to wonder, well, what does the rest of the city look like?

[Falco]: And we need to make sure that, you know,

[Falco]: The stadium's kept up, and I know the people that work there, they do a fine job.

[Falco]: They're doing everything they can, but there also needs to be an infusion of capital to make sure that this stadium is, you know, kept properly for the long term.

[Falco]: So my question, once again, is what's the plan with regard to renovations for Hornall Stadium?

[Falco]: If we could get a report back from the administration on that, I'd greatly appreciate it.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: This actually is a...

[Falco]: So feel the dreams.

[Falco]: We've had feel the dreams now for probably about 10 years, 10, 11 years.

[Falco]: This here is from people that live in the neighborhood.

[Falco]: So dear city council members, I am writing with the support of 28 neighbors to respectfully ask that the resolution 21-543 that Councilor Falco added to the agenda tonight.

[Falco]: regarding a traffic study at the intersection of Auburn, West, North, and Cotting Streets be approved and moved forward rapidly.

[Falco]: Ideally also for the bridge just up the street where Mystic Valley Parkway crosses the river and intersects with Auburn.

[Falco]: Because of the way Cotting, North, West, and Auburn intersect, it is often impossible for drivers coming up one street to have a clear view of the oncoming cars from other directions.

[Falco]: Most cars do not come to a full stop at the stop signs, but even if one does, one's view is frequently blocked by either a parked car or just the angle at which the roads intersect.

[Falco]: An example is turning left onto North Street from Cotting.

[Falco]: It is not a simple four-way stop with two perpendicular streets and requires additional support to be made safe.

[Falco]: No speed bumps are in place to force people to slow down or discourage driving up one-way streets the wrong way.

[Falco]: There are not sufficient curb cuts for strollers and wheelchairs, and most importantly, there is no kind of crosswalk in any direction.

[Falco]: Cars frequently drive up both Cotting and West the wrong way, despite the signage.

[Falco]: This person refers to when her husband in her

[Falco]: and politely stopped, asked drivers to turn around, that this is dangerous for many of the kids that ride bikes and scooters in the neighborhood, that they're going down the wrong way, they get yelled obscenities, and there's a lot of unfortunate back and forth between the neighbors or the people that are just driving down the wrong way.

[Falco]: Parents with kids often discuss how dangerous the street is when we meet at Cummings Park.

[Falco]: Crossing these streets with my two children in a stroller feels incredibly dangerous.

[Falco]: One has to be hypervigilant, constantly looking in multiple directions to make sure a car can see us and won't zoom across and hit us.

[Falco]: The bridge where Mystic Valley Parkway crosses the Mystic River is equally concerning.

[Falco]: Currently, there is debris from a recent accident scattered across the pedestrians' sidewalk.

[Falco]: And once again, the guide rail has been severely damaged in a crash.

[Falco]: It seems like these crashes occur every few weeks, making

[Falco]: making me wonder what factors are making that turn especially dangerous.

[Falco]: Lighting, speed, something else, and how can they be addressed?

[Falco]: Aside from the risks to pedestrians and drivers, these crashes must be costing the city significantly in repairs every time the guide rail gets fixed and a crew must come out to ideally clean up.

[Falco]: They're in demand.

[Falco]: They were actually, pre-COVID, they were packed.

[Falco]: people are starting to go back and planning to go back.

[Falco]: And we need to know what the MBTA is planning for these bus routes.

[Falco]: So it asks that we get some sort of response from our state representatives, state representative Donato.

[Falco]: I know he's been working on this.

[Falco]: We need to know what the plan is going forward.

[Falco]: And these bus routes are key to many people in this community.

[Falco]: I know we had a meeting before.

[Falco]: This has gone back a good couple of years.

[Falco]: I know all of our meetings have a Zoom component and just in the interest of transparency, people know what's going on, they can weigh in.

[Falco]: So.

[Falco]: My point is just making sure that everyone has access to these meetings.

[Falco]: That's the big thing.

[Falco]: Over the last 10 days, along with my city council colleagues, I have taken actions to get answers because the residents of Medford and the city of Medford employees deserve the truth.

[Falco]: Now more than ever, we must think,

[Falco]: have increased awareness about the dynamics of power and vigorously pursue ways to create inclusive and competent work environments.

[Falco]: Although personnel issues are not in the purview of the Medford City Council, we have the responsibility to the employees and to the citizens of Medford to maintain a community of equity and inclusion and to advocate for full transparency.

[Falco]: In the instances described, Mayor Lungo-Koehn and a leadership team have failed Medford and I will not stand by and allow our talented city staff to be tarnished or degraded.

[Falco]: Every single city council have voted to take an independent and impartial investigation into this matter, requested appropriations from the mayor to do so.

[Falco]: In a public document from Mayor Lungo-Koehn to the president of the city council dated June 28th, 2021, the mayor denied this request because

[Falco]: It, and I quote, is nothing more than a political ploy.

[Falco]: For the mayor of the state, the council's request to seek an independent investigation regarding this matter is a political ploy, is an absolute insult, not only to the members of this council, but to the two employees making these allegations.

[Falco]: The statement by the mayor downplays the seriousness

[Falco]: of these allegations dismisses the integrity and reputation of the employee.

[Falco]: It calls into question mayor's integrity and motivation in investigating these matters.

[Falco]: During the council's emergency meeting on June 23rd, city solicitor Kim Scanlon was asked to describe the process of how the third party investigator was selected.

[Falco]: City solicitor Scanlon stated, and I quote, made a recommendation and listed down

[Falco]: to two candidates, and earlier today, the mayor agreed to the first candidate.

[Falco]: This is in complete and total contrast to what the mayor stated in the June 28th letter to President Caraviello.

[Falco]: In that letter, the mayor stated the following, I did not participate in the selection of the third party then or now.

[Falco]: A statement released to the Medford transcript by the city on June 24th, the mayor directed the city solicitor to engage the services of an independent third party selected by the city solicitor.

[Falco]: And you wonder why the council sought to hire an outside counsel and an investigator.

[Falco]: For the mayor to deny the council's request for funds is simply outrageous.

[Falco]: The resolution tonight is basically to get more information

[Falco]: with regard to the private investigator that was hired by the administration on or before June 23rd, 2021.

[Falco]: The bullets points state exactly what I'm looking for.

[Falco]: That's a copy of the signed contract for the investigatory services, a description of the procurement process used for this contract, a detail of funding source, line item and scope of services to be provided

[Falco]: and a copy of the city ordinance the city solicitor is relying on as a basis for the procurement and hiring by the administration for this contract.

[Falco]: I thank you for your time and I move approval.

[Falco]: And I think that's extremely valuable

[Falco]: That's the way I feel about it.

[Falco]: I want to thank President Caraviello for bringing this forward tonight.

[Falco]: I have two received calls regarding this issue, and this needs to be addressed.

[Falco]: It's long overdue.

[Falco]: We weren't invited to the meeting.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: I had the honor to play football for Bud Kelly

[Falco]: from 1985, 1986, and 1987.

[Falco]: And I remember as a sophomore coming to Medford High School and being on the varsity team, it was quite intimidating.

[Falco]: You had a lot of juniors and seniors that played.

[Falco]: It was a great team in 1985.

[Falco]: He was the head coach.

[Falco]: But coming in as a sophomore, everyone at this council was really hit upon it.

[Falco]: It was family.

[Falco]: You came in, it didn't matter where you came from.

[Falco]: It didn't matter who you were, you were family.

[Falco]: And he preached that repeatedly.

[Falco]: And it was about, you know, family, loyalty, being together, having fun, but also being serious too.

[Falco]: When he had to be tough, he was tough, but he was fair.

[Falco]: He was fair with everyone.

[Falco]: It was probably one of the,

[Falco]: You think about, you know, you play sports, you're part of clubs or groups.

[Falco]: And it was probably one of the most fun moments of my life, you know, young life growing up, being 15 years old and being part of that.

[Falco]: And, uh, you know, he was the last coach to win a GBL title in football.

[Falco]: It's been quite some time.

[Falco]: It's been, uh, almost 30 years now, actually more than 30 years.

[Falco]: Uh, but he was, uh, he was, you know, I remember seeing him after graduating and going to high school games, you'd see him as the AD then.

[Falco]: And, uh,

[Falco]: He was just a great guy, always a good friend, and someone who could really make you laugh.

[Falco]: And, you know, he was a great family man.

[Falco]: I remember those games in 1985.

[Falco]: After we won, we'd always drive through Medford Square, pull up on the bus, and I think his wife worked at the dress shop right behind City Hall.

[Falco]: And he'd stop the bus after every win, and everybody would be singing the Mustang Spice Song, and traffic would come to a stop.

[Falco]: And literally he'd get out of the bus, he'd run across the street, his wife would come out and everybody that worked at the shop and he'd give his wife a kiss.

[Falco]: And then he'd come back onto the bus and we'd make our way to the high school.

[Falco]: And, uh, you know, it was just a really fun way to celebrate a victory.

[Falco]: He was a great family man.

[Falco]: And, uh, there was a lot of pride there in blue and white.

[Falco]: If you play Mustang football, blue and white was running through your veins.

[Falco]: If you played any sport, blue and white was running through your veins and he would preach that repeatedly.

[Falco]: And, you know, the community is, this is a big loss to the community.

[Falco]: And my, you know, thoughts and prayers and condolences go to the Kelly, to Judy Kelly and the family.

[Falco]: And he will, he will be missed.

[Falco]: Yes.

[Falco]: you know, and thank you to, you know, thank you for Council Vice President Knight for bringing the resolution tonight.

[Falco]: Thank you Post 45.

[Falco]: And it's important that those 8,700 veterans are remembered.

[Falco]: And I had the opportunity to, I was actually with Vice President Knight and we did, you know, put the flags down at the cemetery.

[Falco]: And it's quite humbling as you walk, you know, among the graves and you're putting them in the ground and it's, you know, literally you have bags and bags of flags, you know,

[Falco]: you know, that represent, you know, the many residents that, you know, volunteer, you know, that were in the Army and Navy, Air Force, Marines, and you name it.

[Falco]: And in many of them, you know, making that ultimate sacrifice.

[Falco]: And when you see that, and you see that the graves and you're walking, you know, row by row, it's, it's amazing that the dedication and commitment to our, to our country into, you know, many of the freedoms that we enjoy today, we have because of that.

[Falco]: And you think about the 77th anniversary of D-Day.

[Falco]: And I had the opportunity about 20 years ago to visit the D-Day beaches in France.

[Falco]: And you walk down the beach and you turn and you see the cliffs in front of you.

[Falco]: And you try, I mean, you can't even imagine that people walking into that and all that fire coming off, you know, all the, you know, you know, just,

[Falco]: the fire from the machine guns and whatnot coming.

[Falco]: I mean, they were just walking into pure hell.

[Falco]: And you think about the sacrifice and the commitment that they made.

[Falco]: And it's amazing.

[Falco]: It's just, I mean, to be there and to see it firsthand, I mean, you see it in the movies, you see it on TV and the different documentaries, but to see it, you hit on the head, the greatest generation.

[Falco]: I mean, to make that sacrifice,

[Falco]: It's just amazing.

[Falco]: And, you know, it is truly the greatest generation.

[Falco]: They should be remembered.

[Falco]: They'll always be remembered.

[Falco]: And you can never thank them enough.

[Falco]: And I think, in the end, if you know a World War II veteran, if there's someone in your neighborhood, it's important, I think, that you really talk to them and hear it firsthand, if you can, because the sacrifices that were made, you know, you don't see a lot of that today.

[Falco]: And it's really a special generation that will, you know, I think always have a special place, you know, in our country.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: During my past four visits to get gas for my car, I've looked at the seal on the gas pump.

[Falco]: It indicates the date when the pump was last inspected by the city's sealer of weights and measures.

[Falco]: Frankly, I've been shocked by how long it has been since these pumps were looked at by the city sealer of weights and measures.

[Falco]: In some cases, it has been as long as three, four years.

[Falco]: For people who don't know, the City Stealer of Weights and Measures is the city employee appointed by the mayor who checks the accuracy of pumps at the gas station, scales at food stores, in the deli or produce departments, or anything that a merchant uses to measure goods that are being sold to the public.

[Falco]: If these pumps or scales are not accurate, the customer will pay more for the gas that they buy for their car or the fruit or cold cuts that they buy for their family.

[Falco]: Pumps and scales that have been unchecked or not properly calibrated by the city ends up with people paying more than they should pay.

[Falco]: And what is worse, they will never know it.

[Falco]: Anytime this happens, it is obviously unfair.

[Falco]: But if it happens because the city has not done its job, it shows a callous disregard for a hardworking residents.

[Falco]: So Mr. President, in addition to the requesting a full list for entities that zero

[Falco]: In addition to requesting a full list for entities that sealer of weights and measures monitors in the date of last inspection and expiration of seal.

[Falco]: I also ask that the mayor advise this council who the sealer of weights and measures is, and when he or she began in that position.

[Falco]: This is something that, you know, even with COVID could have been done.

[Falco]: And as far as I can tell, and I've traveled to numerous gas stations throughout the city,

[Falco]: just to do my own research, I went to probably six to eight gas stations and they're all expired.

[Falco]: This needs to be looked at.

[Falco]: And I also believe that this is a revenue source for the city that they're not taking in.

[Falco]: So this is lost revenue to the city, but it is completely just unfair to the taxpayer that actually buys gas on a regular basis.

[Falco]: And we all do that.

[Falco]: So on that, I'd like to move approval.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: To find out what the fee is for each of the inspections.

[Falco]: to gas inspections, scale inspections at the supermarket.

[Falco]: If I can amend to include that.

[Falco]: That's it.

[Falco]: Mr. President.

[Falco]: We've asked numerous times and we've got nothing back.

[Falco]: I mean, we've asked the administration at least, I think, four times.

[Falco]: Yes.

[Falco]: We've asked them at least four, I think five- Does they get to pick which tent?

[Falco]: It'll be coming to us in a few days.

[Falco]: It makes no sense for the council to wait for a response.

[Falco]: Because we should have had the information by now.

[Falco]: By using the public records law, I will either finally receive a response, or we will all receive a response to the resolutions that we have filed.

[Falco]: It's come to that point.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: As our budget season is quickly approaching, it is time to look at all of our various accounts to see where money is and how it's being spent and to make sure that we finish the year in good shape and start off the next fiscal year in good shape.

[Falco]: Back in 2010, then Mayor McGlynn signed a billboard agreement with Clair Channel.

[Falco]: And the agreement stated that Clear Channel would make a lump payment, an impact fee payment to the city in the year, in the 11th year of the agreement, which would be fiscal year 2021 of $250,000.

[Falco]: And I came across this through some research, basically after the budget was passed.

[Falco]: And when I asked the administration, I was told that this was not factored into the budget,

[Falco]: And that came from the CFO.

[Falco]: And then I was forwarded on to the chief of staff, Dave Rodriguez.

[Falco]: Dave did tell me that they learned of the payment after the budget was prepared and therefore was not part of the budget.

[Falco]: And at that point in time, I asked, well, how's the money being spent?

[Falco]: And the explanation I received was that the city's current plan is to use it for one time unanticipated costs

[Falco]: and emergency health safety costs that cannot be covered by the CARES or FEMA.

[Falco]: For example, let's see, there's an engineer that contacted the mayor's office in a panic that the road work at the bottom of Bedford High School is scheduled to be done.

[Falco]: This is back in August, that they didn't have enough, let's see, that the, was gonna be canceled due to not having necessary funds available.

[Falco]: And the mayor was able to okay this by using these funds from, that they had from the,

[Falco]: from the impact fee.

[Falco]: The section of Harris Park did not have fence, which the city staff were concerned about from a safety perspective.

[Falco]: And they were able to repair this using these funds.

[Falco]: They used these funds for roading control in response to complaints received throughout the community.

[Falco]: And they also used it for road and safety, pedestrian improvements around the city, particularly around the schools.

[Falco]: So that was a plan for the funds, but as we approach the budget season, I'd like to get a full detailed listing of exactly how these funds were spent and how much was spent on each of these projects.

[Falco]: So if we could get, so basically if I could get a detailed itemized listing of how the $250,000 was spent from the billboard agreements, and if we could send that to the CFO and to the chief of staff.

[Falco]: I greatly appreciate and I move approval.

[Falco]: It's good government.

[Falco]: We need to make sure that we're on top of this.

[Falco]: We're coming into a really, really tough budget year.

[Falco]: We all know it.

[Falco]: And we need to have pre-budget meetings.

[Falco]: It's something that everyone on this council supports.

[Falco]: The administration was going to work with us last year on this.

[Falco]: We need to make sure we're working on this.

[Falco]: I know COVID happened.

[Falco]: We need to make sure we're working on this now.

[Falco]: If you take a look,

[Falco]: And I believe the request was, let's just meet with the major departments.

[Falco]: Let's meet with the DPW, the police department, the fire department, just to see what is the budget going to look like.

[Falco]: If you take a look at last year's budget, which I believe was about $185 million, 36 million was a DPW, 14 million, the police department, 14 million, the fire department.

[Falco]: That takes you to about $64 million, I believe about 35% of the budget.

[Falco]: We're only asking to meet with four departments.

[Falco]: I don't think that's too much to ask for.

[Falco]: And if you throw in the school department, which I think is really important to meet with a finance person from on the school side, then you're probably talking about 68% of the budget, but we're only asking for four departments.

[Falco]: You know, the pre-budget meetings are really important.

[Falco]: To me, I think they need to happen.

[Falco]: So President Kavya, I'd like to ask you, have you received any update from the administration as to pre-budget hearings or pre-budget meetings with the department heads?

[Falco]: Is there any type of timeline on that?

[Falco]: at this point, sir.

[Falco]: And I thank you for reaching out on behalf of the council.

[Falco]: I appreciate the attempt.

[Falco]: I find it hard to believe that they haven't, and I'm not saying I don't believe you, but I have a hard time thinking that the administration hasn't talked budget yet and here we are in March.

[Falco]: I mean, the budget hearings, when you think about it, they're probably going to be sometime maybe early June.

[Falco]: So I would think they need to be talking about budget now, and we need to be part of that conversation.

[Falco]: If you take a look at the school side, Councilor Scarpelli, Councilor Locke, you on the school committee, you remember this, we had pre-budget hearings.

[Falco]: We met with the department heads in February, March, April.

[Falco]: By the time you got to the budget, there were no surprises.

[Falco]: We need to make sure that's happening on the city side as well.

[Falco]: So thank you for bringing this forward.

[Falco]: I want to thank Councilor Biaz for bringing this forward.

[Falco]: I agree wholeheartedly with everything that my colleagues have mentioned so far.

[Falco]: This is a problem that's been going on for years, unfortunately.

[Falco]: When I was in the school committee with Councilor Scarapelli, we were on the school committee for six years, and this is something that we battled with since day one.

[Falco]: Every year, the charter school would have a ton of cash on hand.

[Falco]: They would literally have cash on hand.

[Falco]: They would pay for projects with cash.

[Falco]: Meanwhile, we would scrap trying to figure out how we're gonna pay for different departments.

[Falco]: We would go with no department heads, no supplies.

[Falco]: I mean, this has to stop at some point.

[Falco]: and the state really needs to get involved.

[Falco]: And what they really need to do is sit down and come up with a permanent solution to this problem.

[Falco]: It's not fair that every year, you know, our local schools get hammered over the head because we don't have the funding.

[Falco]: We could always use more funding, yes, but this is a key component to the formula, to our funding here locally.

[Falco]: And, you know, to lose a million dollars, if not more,

[Falco]: And it happens year after year after year, it needs to be addressed.

[Falco]: Our state legislators need to do something about this.

[Falco]: This is just wrong.

[Falco]: And Councilor Biarzi, thank you for bringing this forward.

[Falco]: And I support 100% move approval.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: Recently, Anthony Bonner, a longtime Methodist resident, probably for about 40 years, lived in the Washington Street Park Street area.

[Falco]: He was a member of the Shriners Club, or he was a Shriner, I should say.

[Falco]: And what it is, is it basically takes recycled asphalt, and actually they use it to pave the street again.

[Falco]: There are numerous benefits to the process, shorter construction times, it's easier to use around catch basins and manholes and water valves and whatnot.

[Falco]: for current spend for this fiscal year, meaning since July.

[Falco]: of so many, the pandemic has caused significant financial hardship to so many.

[Falco]: One of the basic needs of all people is for housing.

[Falco]: And for so many, this basic need has been undetermined by the possibility of eviction.

[Falco]: Among the attempts to address this need have included the state's pause on evictions that expired on October 7, 2020.

[Falco]: Also, the CDC, Centers for Disease Prevention and Control, established a federal moratorium on residential evictions that I believe will expire on March 31, 2021.

[Falco]: The purpose of my resolution is to prompt a City Council discussion with an eye on passing an ordinance requiring property owners who are serving tenants an eviction notice to include with it a notice of tenants' rights and resources.

[Falco]: This type of notice would include a description of the various rights of tenants and a list of resources that they may be able to utilize.

[Falco]: All too often, tenants are unaware of their rights and do not know that there are resources available to them.

[Falco]: Stability requires many things, but first among them is knowledge.

[Falco]: I ask the council to support this resolution and to focus on a discussion of this subject at a committee of the whole meeting or a subcommittee meeting.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: If you could get us any additional information, that would be greatly appreciated.

[Falco]: I have another question with regard to the artifacts.

[Falco]: If you find artifacts, I assume they're going to find some artifacts, what would happen to those artifacts?

[Falco]: Did they go to the historical society?

[Falco]: Did they go to the library?

[Falco]: Is there any thought as to where those would go?

[Falco]: Who would own those?

[Falco]: And that's what I was thinking as well, that it would go to one of those two spots.

[Falco]: And if I can make it as part of the committee to report that they either go to the Historical Society or the New History Room within the Medford Public Library.

[Falco]: And the other question is, if these funds are approved, when do you foresee the work beginning with regard to the archaeological dig and the work on the

[Falco]: the Grove Street Wall and the Slave Wall.

[Falco]: This calendar year, do you know specifically, would it be around the summertime or?

[Falco]: Okay, thank you, Mr. Carr.

[Falco]: You're welcome.

[Falco]: My correct?

[Falco]: If I may, my amendment was to, that either go, the artifacts either go to the Medford Public Library History Room or the Medford Historic Society.

[Falco]: Either or.

[Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Falco]: And I want to thank my colleagues for bringing this forward as well.

[Falco]: You know, I think back to when this process first started a while back and it got off to a rough start, but then

[Falco]: You know, as a council, we really kind of worked with the hospital and the residents to bring this back on, as Councilor Scarpelli said, back on the rails.

[Falco]: And actually, we had monthly meetings.

[Falco]: And those monthly meetings were well attended when we had people in the chambers.

[Falco]: And it was good back and forth between the residents, the council, and the hospital.

[Falco]: And that went really well.

[Falco]: You know, and I can't thank enough the members of the CAG, the Community Advisory Group, for all the work that they did representing the neighborhood and for the councils for asking all of their great questions through the process.

[Falco]: And it is sad to hear that, you know, maybe things have gone off the rails a little bit.

[Falco]: And I think now more than ever, the hospital really needs to engage with the community

[Falco]: with the community advisory group.

[Falco]: And if there's going to be a second iteration of that group, and there are going to be new members, I think it's important that there is a back and forth, and there is a constant dialogue between the hospital, between the community group, and between the council.

[Falco]: Now more than ever, when things, when the project is, you know,

[Falco]: nearing its point of completion.

[Falco]: And you're really, I think, going to start to see a lot of quality of life issues that impact that neighborhood on a daily basis.

[Falco]: And the hospital needs to come to the table and communicate with that community advisory group and the council.

[Falco]: And I'm really interested to hear and get an update tonight as to what's going on.

[Falco]: But I really, really believe that now more than ever, we need to make sure that the hospital is engaging with the residents to make sure that we can ensure a good quality of life up in that neighborhood when this comes to completion.

[Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Falco]: Mr. President.

[Falco]: Councilor Felkel.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: One of the most important responsibilities we have each year is to review and either pass or reject the city budget.

[Falco]: You know, tonight I offer this resolution to shed light on a process that I think is somewhat flawed.

[Falco]: You know, every year we meet in June with the city of Medford department heads to discuss their budget and discuss the proposed budget for the upcoming year.

[Falco]: More often than not, it's our only formal meeting that we have with department heads throughout the year.

[Falco]: And I think more often than not,

[Falco]: Those meetings become more, we're asking questions probably that are more than just budget related questions.

[Falco]: Sometimes they're policy questions and whatnot.

[Falco]: So this here tonight is basically a proactive approach that I'm asking President Caraviello if in the upcoming months of February, March, April, and May, if you could schedule pre-budget hearings with each of our department heads to go over their current budget,

[Falco]: To take a look at the goals and objectives to see if they're accomplishing

[Falco]: what they've said that their goals and objectives are for this current year.

[Falco]: So basically, it's a proactive approach, and it gives us an opportunity to ask department heads questions that sometimes aren't even budget related.

[Falco]: So it's to hopefully streamline the budget process when we discuss the budget in June.

[Falco]: So I think that we have to pass this budget, or actually pass or reject this budget each year.

[Falco]: This is really large, and we need to make sure that we have all the information that we need to make that decision.

[Falco]: And I think meeting with department heads more than once a year is something that we should be doing.

[Falco]: Me meeting them once a year to have a quick budget meeting in June, to me, doesn't cut it.

[Falco]: So I think that what we need to do is budget meetings so we can actually have a nice conversation that is full of information.

[Falco]: And if there's items that we need to follow up on or they need to follow up on, that's fine.

[Falco]: We're not doing it last minute in June.

[Falco]: So therefore, I would ask if you could please schedule budget meetings, maybe two or three a month.

[Falco]: Starting in February would be ideal.

[Falco]: So I would respectfully ask for my colleagues to support this and I move approval.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Falco]: Recently, I received calls from residents regarding the C-Click Fix program.

[Falco]: For many people that might not know, that's a program that we use to basically, the residents can enter into any type of issues that they're having, and then they're assigned to the appropriate department head where hopefully they can be resolved in a timely fashion.

[Falco]: Recently, I was notified that

[Falco]: The issues that were logged by a number of residents were basically cleared out and deleted.

[Falco]: So they no longer appear on the list of outstanding issues.

[Falco]: And from what I'm hearing, this is the second time that this has happened.

[Falco]: I think when the previous administration crossed over to the current administration, they cleared out C-Click Fix.

[Falco]: And then when recently, I think they may have an upgrade or something, and they did the same thing, they cleared out issues again.

[Falco]: So what they're doing is basically they're clearing out issues that have never been resolved.

[Falco]: And I think one of the reasons why it was closed was because it was a seasonal issue.

[Falco]: It may be an issue that couldn't be dealt with because the weather was getting cold.

[Falco]: But from my opinion, that doesn't mean that the issue's gone away.

[Falco]: And I think that's what's happening now is we're losing, there's really no transparency when something like this happens.

[Falco]: Because if you're just deleting issues because maybe you can't

[Falco]: take care of them in the wintertime, that doesn't mean that the issue's gone away.

[Falco]: That means the issue still exists, it should still be in the list.

[Falco]: And then what happens is they get this email back saying that it's a seasonal issue, and then they ask the person, I believe, if it's been resolved.

[Falco]: As far as I'm concerned, that's the city's responsibility, is whether or not an issue's been resolved, because the ticket's been assigned to someone in the city.

[Falco]: So if we could please get an update from the city administration as to what's going on with CClickFix.

[Falco]: If issues are being deleted, why?

[Falco]: Councilor Knight, if you wouldn't mind, what time did that email come in at?

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: If I may, if I could also amend my resolution to find out what it means when they say fit method and our needs.

[Falco]: So I guess C-Click Fix needs to work differently in Medford than it does anywhere else.

[Falco]: So I would like to know if they could please specify what that means.

[Falco]: Because I think there's a lot of uncertainty right now as to C-Click Fix, how it's managed,

[Falco]: how it operates, when you're deleting issues that haven't been resolved, I have a problem with that.

[Falco]: Basically, you're saying the issue doesn't exist anymore when it does.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: On the motion by Councilor Falco.

[Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Falco]: I just want to thank all my colleagues for their support on this here.

[Falco]: And Councilor Knight mentioned, I think, an important part about data-driven decision-making.

[Falco]: And if you don't have the systems in place to give you that data, the decisions aren't going to be, you're really not going to be able to use it as a tool.

[Falco]: And you're right, Councilor Marks mentioned it before about using it as a tool.

[Falco]: It's important to have that tool available.

[Falco]: And Councilor Scarpelli, you hit it on the head.

[Falco]: With regard to resources, if it's not managed properly, it's not going to help anyone.

[Falco]: So if you wouldn't mind, if we could also schedule committee the whole with the administration to actually, if it's training fine, but to learn more about the new system, that would be great.

[Falco]: And to find out what we can get out of it.

[Falco]: It would be nice to know if there's any type of reporting that we can get out of this system.

[Falco]: I know when we first went to see quick fix, I asked about that.

[Falco]: They said there was nothing, which I find hard to believe, but I would hope.

[Falco]: Well, I would think that there should be some sort of reporting that we can access to see what's being done, what's not being done, what's being resolved, what we can use, how we can look at the data, what type of calls are coming in.

[Falco]: And it'll really help with the budget process at the end of the year when we take a look at that and see all the work that's been done.

[Falco]: I know there's work that's getting done.

[Falco]: But I also know that it needs to be managed correctly and if we're just closing tickets for the sake of closing tickets, it's not very transparent and it doesn't mean that the issue goes away.

[Falco]: Thank you everyone for your support, and I move approval.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: 38th regular meeting of the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[Falco]: Clerk Herneviz, please call the roll.

[Falco]: Present.

[Falco]: President, all seven members are present.

[Falco]: At this point in time, I'd ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Falco]: specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen.

[Falco]: or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Falco]: In the event that we aren't able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website, an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Falco]: Hearings.

[Falco]: Do we have time for this?

[Falco]: Hearings, legal notice 20-673.

[Falco]: petition for grant of location, National Grid and Verizon, North Andover, Massachusetts, locations of poles, wires, and fixtures, Medford, Massachusetts, city clerk's office.

[Falco]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, the Medford City Council will hold a public hearing via Zoom on Tuesday, December 22nd, 2020.

[Falco]: A link to be posted no later than Friday.

[Falco]: Excuse me, excuse me.

[Falco]: I have to read the meeting notice and then at that point I will recognize you and we will begin the process.

[Falco]: No worries, thank you.

[Falco]: You are hereby notified of that by order of the Medford City Council.

[Falco]: The Medford City Council will hold the public hearing via Zoom on Tuesday, December 22nd, 2020, a link to be posted no later than Friday, December 8th, 2020, on a petition of Massachusetts Electrical Company, DBA, National Grid, and Verizon New England for permission to locate poles, wires, and fixtures, including necessary sustaining and protecting fixtures along and across the public way

[Falco]: or ways, herein named, said poles, wires, and fixtures to be located substantially in accordance with the plan marked Mitchell Ave., meant for Massachusetts, and filed in the office of the city clerk.

[Falco]: Wherever it prays that after due notice and hearing, as provided by law, it be granted a location for and permission to erect and maintain poles and wires, together with sustaining and protecting fixtures,

[Falco]: As it may find necessary, said poles to be erected substantially in accordance with the plan filed herewith marked Mitchell Ave, Medford, Massachusetts, and available for inspection.

[Falco]: In the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 103-85, George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[Falco]: The following are the streets and highways referred to.

[Falco]: Mitchell Ave, national grid to install one,

[Falco]: J.O.

[Falco]: pole on Mitchell Ave beginning at a point approximately 14 feet east of the center line.

[Falco]: Install one new joint pole P2818 approximately 60 feet northeast of existing pole P3817 near 93 Mitchell Ave.

[Falco]: Location approximately as shown on plan filed in the office of the city clerk.

[Falco]: This was approved by the city engineer with the following conditions.

[Falco]: Engineering Division recommends that this grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[Falco]: Number one, the grant of location is limited to this one joint owned J.O.

[Falco]: pole as described in the petition.

[Falco]: National grid to install one J.O.

[Falco]: pole on Mitchell Ave beginning at a point approximately 14 feet east of the center line.

[Falco]: Install one new joint pole P3818 approximately 60 feet northeast of the existing pole P3817 in 93 Mitchell Avenue.

[Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify dig safe and shall obtain all applicable permits.

[Falco]: for the engineering division.

[Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other apparatuses are adversely impacted.

[Falco]: National Grid shall ensure that all sewer water and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Falco]: Number four, the new pole location is located within the furniture zone of the concrete sidewalk.

[Falco]: Any disturbance of the curb-to-curb concrete backing must be repaired to the satisfaction of the city engineer.

[Falco]: The sidewalk panel must be replaced in kind in the pole surrounded by an expansion joint.

[Falco]: Number five, the project must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris.

[Falco]: for the duration of the installation.

[Falco]: Approved by the superintendent of wires, call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations or aids.

[Falco]: Plans can be viewed in the city clerk's office, 781-393-2425, Adam L. Herdeby, city clerk.

[Falco]: Offered by Council on 8.

[Falco]: Be it resolved that the rules of the Medford City Council be amended as follows.

[Falco]: New section.

[Falco]: Public hearings.

[Falco]: Matters requiring public hearing before the City Council shall be conducted as follows.

[Falco]: Number 1.

[Falco]: The petition is read into the record.

[Falco]: Number 2.

[Falco]: The petitioner provides an explanation of the matter requiring a public hearing.

[Falco]: Number 3.

[Falco]: The public hearing is conducted.

[Falco]: Number four, following the public hearing, a six calendar day public comment period shall commence.

[Falco]: Public comments shall be submitted in writing to the clerk.

[Falco]: Number five, the council shall neither approve nor deny any public require, I'm sorry.

[Falco]: Number five, the council shall neither approve nor deny any matter requiring public hearing until the conclusion of the public comment period

[Falco]: and less waived by a majority vote of the council.

[Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: You have to have a meeting on that because it's already been voted to go to subcommittee.

[Falco]: So let's see, next item is communications from the mayor, 20-687, December 18th, 2020.

[Falco]: to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts 02155 regarding Community Preservation Committee.

[Falco]: Dear Mr. President and City Councilors, I respectfully submit the following recommendations of the Community Preservation Committee to the City Council for their consideration.

[Falco]: Requesting the appropriation of $30,000 from the CPA Historic Preservation Reserve to the Medford Brooks Estate Land Trust Incorporated for phase three of the restoration of an historic stone wall at the Brooks Estate.

[Falco]: Requesting the appropriation of $275,000 from the CPA General Reserve to the City of Medford Public Library for the Medford Public Library exterior space project.

[Falco]: Requesting an appropriation of $76,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the City of Medford Parks Division for the rehabilitation of the Placed at Park basketball court.

[Falco]: requesting the appropriation of $15,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the City of Medford Parks Division for the playground resurfacing at Tufts, Capon and Cummings Park.

[Falco]: Requesting the appropriation of $293,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the City of Medford Parks Division for rehabilitation of Duggar Park Tennis Courts.

[Falco]: requesting the appropriation of $40,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the City of Medford Conservation Commission for the Riverside Avenue stormwater improvements.

[Falco]: Requesting the appropriation of $322,000 from the CPA General Reserve to the City of Medford Recreation Department for the rehabilitation and improvements at Tufts Pool.

[Falco]: All projects will be tracked in the Community Preservation Fund by category, open space, historic preservation, and general reserve.

[Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehnman.

[Falco]: So I believe we have Roberta Cameron with us tonight.

[Falco]: And we have Danielle Evans.

[Falco]: I'm going to unmute them just in case anyone has any questions.

[Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained therein.

[Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website, an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email our city clerk, A Hurtubise, that is A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at medford-ma.gov.

[Falco]: internet issues here at city hall.

[Falco]: That is Adam her to me is once again, that is a H U R T U B I S E at

[Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford High School Hall of Famer, Brian Branson, be recognized and officially honored by the City of Medford for his several decades of unselfish volunteerism and commitment to Medford High student-athletes and sport programs.

[Falco]: Councilor Marks.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: And if I may quickly, I first met Brian Branson when I was 15 years old.

[Falco]: I was a sophomore at High School.

[Falco]: And like Councilor Marks mentioned, Brian was the team manager for the football team.

[Falco]: And believe it or not, I played football.

[Falco]: And, but he was, he's just an amazing, amazing person in, you know,

[Falco]: people like Brian are people that you want in your community.

[Falco]: And I remember being 15 years old and I remember learning, you know, right away from coach Bud Kelly, you know, and he would always talk about, you know, blue and white running through your veins.

[Falco]: You have blue and white running through your veins.

[Falco]: And that was all about Mustang football and being dedicated and committed and being someone who was committed to the team, but also committed to the city and working hard.

[Falco]: And that's someone, and I will tell you something, there is no one that has

[Falco]: We're blue and white running through their veins and Brian Branson.

[Falco]: He is a remarkable person who

[Falco]: just, you know, just very dedicated to our community, dedicated to sports at the high school for years.

[Falco]: And like Councilor Mark said, I think at least probably 20 years that he was a statistician at the high school, you know, working with the football team and the baseball team.

[Falco]: And I remember seeing him every Saturday when I played.

[Falco]: And then after that, I'd come back and he was still there and he was still doing it and he loved it.

[Falco]: And he loved giving back and,

[Falco]: And, you know, later on in life, he decided, well, I'm going to be an umpire.

[Falco]: And I remember saying to him, you sure you want to do that?

[Falco]: And he wanted to do it and he loves doing it.

[Falco]: And I know he goes out to Cooperstown every year to, you know, to actually the home of our, actually that's where our city clerk was born and raised.

[Falco]: But he, Brian would go out there every year to umpire baseball games for the whole weekend.

[Falco]: And he loved it, and he enjoyed it, and he always gave back.

[Falco]: And so I think this is a very fitting honor.

[Falco]: Council Marks, I thank you for bringing this forward.

[Falco]: Councilor Scarpelli and Council Marks, you both hit it on the head with the words that you had to say.

[Falco]: He's completely committed to our city, to the youth of our community, and it's a well-deserved honor.

[Falco]: So on the motion of Councilor Marks, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Falco]: December 1st, 2020, to President John Falco and honorable members of the Medford City Council, from Rianna Lungo-Koehn mayor, regarding licensing of food trucks.

[Falco]: Dear President Falco and members of the Medford City Council, I respectfully request that the City Council approve the following list of food trucks for events.

[Falco]: that are scheduled for the coming months due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

[Falco]: In the city's temporary policies, limiting events and gatherings, the attached application includes some unique considerations, which have been reviewed and approved by my office, as well as the Board of Health.

[Falco]: Method streets updated request.

[Falco]: Location dates to be determined by resident request, seeking up to five locations between November and March, requesting one lunch,

[Falco]: and or dinner in one dessert truck per location and or date.

[Falco]: Thank you for your consideration.

[Falco]: Respectfully submitted, Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn.

[Falco]: Communications from the Mayor, 20656, November 25th, 2020, to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[Falco]: Dear Mr. President and City Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that the City Council authorize me, as Mayor, on behalf of the City of Medford, to enter into a tax increment financing, TIF, TIF,

[Falco]: agreement with Monogram Gourmet Foods LLC in accordance with the Massachusetts Economic Development Incentive Program, EDIP, and Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 23A, Chapter 40, Section 59, and Chapter 59.

[Falco]: I will be present at the meeting with members of the administration, Chief Assessor Ellen Bordeaux, Jeffrey Monica from Monogram Gourmet Foods, and Maria DeStefano from the Massachusetts Office of Business Development to discuss the agreement as well as Monogram Gourmet Foods plan for the proposed operation in the city of Medford.

[Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Falco]: I'd ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America.

[Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Falco]: The meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Falco]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties.

[Falco]: With the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen and or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email the city clerk, Adam Hertubez at A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at medford-ma.gov.

[Falco]: Yes.

[Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law chapter 38, section 18, and the governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation

[Falco]: on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting in the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Falco]: Specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen,

[Falco]: or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website in audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email the city clerk and his email address is

[Falco]: H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at Medford-MA.gov.

[Falco]: That is A Hertubis at Medford-MA.gov.

[Falco]: This is a continuation of a public hearing from last week.

[Falco]: Okay, so that has been tabled to December 8th.

[Falco]: The notice of a public hearing, 20-622 petition for grant of location, National Grid, gas main locations, Medford, Massachusetts, City Clerk's office.

[Falco]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, Medford City Council will hold a public hearing via Zoom on November 17th, 2020.

[Falco]: 2020, a link to be posted no later than Friday, November 13th, 2020 on a petition of Boston Gas DBA National Grid for permission to locate gas mains as herein after described for the transmission of gas in and under the following public streets, lanes, highways, and places of the city of Medford.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Marks, seconded by Councilor Knight, to waive the reading to have a brief synopsis from a representative from National Grid.

[Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[Falco]: President Falco.

[Falco]: The motion passes.

[Falco]: Ms.

[Falco]: Cuddy, if you could please give us a brief synopsis of the project.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: This here has been approved by the chief engineer with the following conditions.

[Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the grant application be approved with the following conditions.

[Falco]: Number one, the grant application is limited to approximately 532 feet of plastic gas main as described in the petition.

[Falco]: To install and maintain approximately 532 feet of new four-inch plastic main extension from the existing two-inch plastic main in the Whitty Hill Road going on to Medford Street and extending to the service location at 87 Medford.

[Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE.

[Falco]: It shall obtain all applicable permits.

[Falco]: from the engineering division.

[Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances.

[Falco]: are adversely impacted, National Grid shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Falco]: Number four, the sidewalk and street restoration must be done in consultation with the engineering division and per the requirements of an approved street opening permit.

[Falco]: The concrete sidewalk must be replaced in kind and cleanly cut at the control joints.

[Falco]: The de minimis concrete pavement over the trench shall be milled and overlaid as described below.

[Falco]: A Winter Hill Road includes approximately 130 feet of new gas main.

[Falco]: This section of the street also includes trench patches associated with gas service work.

[Falco]: Winter Hill Road should be restored with a mill and overlay that encompasses past national grid patches.

[Falco]: B, the side of Medford Street with the proposed main includes multiple gas related trench patches that extend to the center seam of the roadway asphalt.

[Falco]: It also includes trenches associated with other utility connections for 87 Medford Street.

[Falco]: The Medford Street surface restoration should include mill and overlay from curb to central line seam.

[Falco]: C, it is the understanding of the engineering division that the owner of the 87 Method Street project will provide the street restoration.

[Falco]: The engineering division takes no exception to the owner providing this scope.

[Falco]: However, National Grid remains responsible for confirming that the restoration is performed in accordance with this grant of location, the standards of the city of Medford, and the associated street opening permit.

[Falco]: Number five, the new four inch gas main appears to be offset with the existing drain line by approximately three feet.

[Falco]: This offset should be confirmed and maintained.

[Falco]: Number six, the new four inch gas main appears to pass in between two drainage structures near 85 Medford Street.

[Falco]: The condition of these structures in lateral must be verified before and after construction with the highway division.

[Falco]: Number seven, pavement markings must be restored.

[Falco]: Number eight, the project site must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[Falco]: Number nine, Medford Street is a highly traveled roadway for vehicles as well as pedestrians.

[Falco]: A detailed traffic management plan must be submitted to the engineering division for review and approved prior to receiving

[Falco]: a street opening permit.

[Falco]: The TMP traffic management plan must include accommodations for pedestrians in addition to vehicles.

[Falco]: Number 10, the plan submitted with the petition is not stamped by a professional engineer.

[Falco]: National grid must, must submit a professional engineer stamp plan to the engineering division prior to release of a street opening permit.

[Falco]: Number 11, only one service is shown 87 Medford street.

[Falco]: This project is limited to that one service.

[Falco]: If national grid,

[Falco]: Plans to provide additional services, especially to the east side of Medford Street as part of this project, the engineering division must be notified and the surface restoration must be curb to curb.

[Falco]: Call 781-393-2501 for any accommodation.

[Falco]: AIDS, TDD, 781-393-2516.

[Falco]: For further information, contact the city clerk at 781-393-2425.

[Falco]: The city of Medford is an EEO, AA 504 employer.

[Falco]: By order of the city council, Adam L. Herdeby, city clerk.

[Falco]: At this point, I would declare the public hearing open.

[Falco]: Open to those in favor of the petition.

[Falco]: Ms.

[Falco]: Cuddy, would you just give your name and address for the record, please, if you are in favor?

[Falco]: Thank you very much.

[Falco]: Is there anyone else that is in favor of the petition that would like to speak?

[Falco]: Anyone?

[Falco]: Okay, hearing and seeing none, I declare this portion of the hearing closed.

[Falco]: Anyone in opposition of the petition?

[Falco]: Is there anyone online tonight that is in opposition to the petition that would like to speak?

[Falco]: Okay, hearing and seeing none, I declare this portion of the hearing closed.

[Falco]: Do any of the councilors have questions?

[Falco]: Tim McGivern, I'm going to unmute you.

[Falco]: Okay, Tim McGivern, City Engineer.

[Falco]: Hi, Tim.

[Falco]: Yes.

[Falco]: Yeah.

[Falco]: Tim, that was to you.

[Falco]: The 30th regular meeting in the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[Falco]: She is not present.

[Falco]: Present.

[Falco]: President, six members present, one absence.

[Falco]: At this point in time, I'd ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag.

[Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting in the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Falco]: specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings of real time via technological means.

[Falco]: In the event that we aren't able to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website in audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Falco]: participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email the city clerk, ahertubise, that will be A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E, at medford-ma.gov.

[Falco]: Let's see, motions, orders, and resolutions.

[Falco]: 20-602 offered by Councilor Marks be it resolved that the Medford City Council hold a caucus on Tuesday, October 27th at 6.30 p.m.

[Falco]: for the purpose of electing a president and vice president for calendar year 21.

[Falco]: Councilor Marks.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: Actually, I'm sorry.

[Falco]: On motion of Councilor Marks, seconded by Vice President Capiello, Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: A motion to table is undebatable.

[Falco]: and it needs to be seconded.

[Falco]: So on the motion of Council of Bears to table this matter, seconded by.

[Falco]: Does this motion have a second?

[Falco]: Okay, seeing and hearing none.

[Falco]: This does not have a second, so it cannot be tabled.

[Falco]: Would anybody else like to speak on this matter?

[Falco]: Okay, if I may, before we go any further, if my colleagues would not mind me speaking on this, I'd like to thank Councilor Marks for bringing this forward, especially in the interest of clarity and transparency.

[Falco]: I'd just like to mention that the role of the Council President

[Falco]: has taken on more responsibilities than ever before, especially over the past year during this pandemic.

[Falco]: And while I have very much enjoyed my two terms as council president and take a great deal of pride in fulfilling this role, I have decided not to pursue the presidency for another term.

[Falco]: I look forward to returning to the floor as an active participant, which will enable me to pursue the issues that mean a lot to our community,

[Falco]: And I look forward to working with the next Council President, whoever he or she may be.

[Falco]: So I just wanted to make that statement so everyone knows.

[Falco]: And if they decide that they want to pursue the presidency, they absolutely can and should.

[Falco]: So on the motion of Council of Marks, seconded by Vice President Caraviello.

[Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[Falco]: Yes.

[Falco]: That is five in the affirmative, one in the negative, and one absent.

[Falco]: The motion passes.

[Falco]: 20606, October 8th, 2020, to Brianna Lugo, current mayor, from Kimberly M. Scanlon, city solicitor, regarding council paper 20-476.

[Falco]: Dear Mayor Lungo-Koehn, on October 8th, 2020, the Medford City Council have made a request to include a 3% tax in the draft Cannabis Advisory Committee Ordinance.

[Falco]: However, since General Law Chapter 64N, Section 3 is a local option statute, the preferred method is for the Council to accept the provisions of the statute pursuant to General Law Chapter 4, Section 4.

[Falco]: For convenience purposes, I have included the following format below.

[Falco]: Be it resolved that the City of Medford, through its City Council, accept the provisions of General Law, Chapter 64N, Section 3, and impose a local excise tax on the sale or transfer of marijuana products for adult use to anyone other than a marijuana establishment at a rate of 3%.

[Falco]: Respectfully submitted, Kimberly M. Scanlon, City Solicitor.

[Falco]: On the motion of council night, seconded by Vice President Caraviello.

[Falco]: Any questions from the council or comments?

[Falco]: Anyone have the hand up?

[Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law chapter 38, section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Falco]: Specific information and general guidelines.

[Falco]: For remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Falco]: No in-person attendance or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Falco]: And the motion of Vice President Caraviello to suspend the rule is seconded by Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: 20-587, October 1st, 2020, to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, regarding COVID-19 monthly update.

[Falco]: Dear Mr. President, members of the City Council, in response to the Council's request for monthly COVID-19 updates from the administration, Medford Board of Health Director, Marian O'Connor, will be present at the regular City Council meeting scheduled for Tuesday, October 6th, 2020, to provide an update

[Falco]: to provide an update on the city's response to COVID-19.

[Falco]: The latest community data and other relevant data and information as available.

[Falco]: The updates Mary Ann or designee will provide include but are not limited to.

[Falco]: Latest positivity rate.

[Falco]: Currently we are posting case numbers daily to www.medfordma.org slash coronavirus dash information, as well as state data on a weekly basis and full breakdowns of positivity and death rates by race and ethnicity on a monthly basis.

[Falco]: We can answer additional questions regarding this data, our stage designated color code and what the data means for our reopening plans in Medford.

[Falco]: Tufts University updates.

[Falco]: We can break down the university's public dashboard with positivity rates, tests completed to date, and answer any questions regarding Tufts-specific COVID-19 plans.

[Falco]: Reopening plans and related information.

[Falco]: Of particular interest for October, the state has announced that cities and towns may proceed to phase three, step two, as of October 5th.

[Falco]: as long as the community is not in the red category.

[Falco]: We can provide information about Method Step 2 plans and protocols.

[Falco]: Additional updates and information as necessary and available, we will provide updates on programs and resources like the city's RUOK program for seniors, upcoming flu vaccine clinics, and using these to prepare the potential future COVID-19 vaccine clinics, updates on nursing home data and schools and other information.

[Falco]: Marianne or another member of my team will be available to the first city council meeting each month to provide these updates as requested, and we will answer any additional questions you may have.

[Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn mayor.

[Falco]: Be it ordained by the Medford City Council that the revised ordinances of the city of Medford, as most recently amended, is hereby further amended by changing the language of chapter 74.

[Falco]: Streets, sidewalks, and other public places, article three, sidewalks, section 74-114, entitled Removal of Snow and Ice.

[Falco]: said section presently states section 74-114, removal of snow and ice.

[Falco]: A, whenever the sidewalk or any part of the sidewalk adjoining any building or a lot of land of any street is encumbered with ice and snow, it shall be the duty of the tenant or occupant and in case there should be no tenant or occupant of the whole of such building a lot of land, it shall be the duty of the owner

[Falco]: with a person having care of the sidewalk or to cause such sidewalk to have been made safe, convenient for public use or travel by removing the ice or snow or by covering the area with sand or some other suitable substance.

[Falco]: In case such tenant, occupant, owner, or other person shall neglect to do so for the space of six hours during the daytime, he shall forfeit and pay the sum of $25 for the first events

[Falco]: 50 for each successive date that the sidewalk shall continue to be encumbered.

[Falco]: B, any person shall not throw or put or cause to be thrown or put any snow or ice into any street in the city.

[Falco]: The fine for violation of this section shall be for the first offense $50, for the second offense and subsequent offenses $100.

[Falco]: The language of said section 74-14 shall hereby be amended to read as follows.

[Falco]: Section 74-114, removal of snow and ice.

[Falco]: A, whenever snow or ice accumulates on a sidewalk, the owner of any land or building abutting a sidewalk or walking path shall remove the snow and ice to permit safe passage for pedestrians on the sidewalk abutting the owner's property and the entrance to the pedestrian crossing abutting the sidewalk.

[Falco]: The owner shall also remove snow at a fire hydrant within or abutting the sidewalk that abuts the owner's property sufficient to

[Falco]: allow fire department access to the hydrant.

[Falco]: The owner shall remove the snow or ice or treat the sidewalk with sand or any other suitable material to permit safe passage to pedestrians.

[Falco]: The owner shall remove snow and ice within six daylight hours after the snow stops falling and the city may extend the deadline set forth above in its discretion.

[Falco]: The city's code enforcement officer or his designee or the police department shall notify the owner of the failure to comply and allow the owner 24 hours to comply.

[Falco]: For residential properties, if the owner does not comply within 24 hours of receiving notice, the city may in its discretion remove.

[Falco]: removal as a lien on the owner's property tax to fine the owner $50 per day until the owner complies.

[Falco]: For such subsequent offense within 12 months, the fine or charge shall double.

[Falco]: For commercial properties, if the owner does not comply within 24 hours of the receiving notice, the city may, in its discretion, remove the snow or ice and charge the owner for the removal as a lien on the owner's property tax bill

[Falco]: will fine the owner $100 per day until the owner complies.

[Falco]: For each subsequent offense within 12 months, the fine or charge shall double.

[Falco]: B, a person shall not throw or put or cause to be thrown or put any snow or ice into any street in the city.

[Falco]: The fine for violation of this section shall be, for residential property owners, $50 for the first offense, $100 for the second offense and subsequent offenses.

[Falco]: The fine for commercial property owners, $100 for the first offense and $200 for the second offense and subsequent offenses.

[Falco]: Vice President Caraviello.

[Falco]: Oh, yes.

[Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Falco]: specific information, and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email the clerk, Adam Herdebes at A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at MedfordMA.gov.

[Falco]: That's Medford-MA.gov.

[Falco]: On September 22, 2020, a link to be posted no later than Friday, September 18, 2020, on a petition of the Boston Gas Company, DBA, and National Grid for permission to locate gas mains, as hereinafter described for the transmission of gas, and under the following public streets, lanes, highways, and places of the city of Medford, and of the pipes, valves, governors, manholes, and other structures, fixtures, and

[Falco]: appurtenances designed or intended to... On the motion of council, I'll ask to waive the remainder of the reading, seconded by council.

[Falco]: Clerk, please call the roll.

[Falco]: Seven affirmative, zero negative.
