[Falco]: So let's see.

[Falco]: And if I may, I'm going to just read that this was approved by the chief engineer with the following conditions.

[Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[Falco]: Number one, the grant of location is limited to the approximately 60 feet of gas main in one service located in Medford that is part of the larger project described in the GOL documents as follows.

[Falco]: To install and maintain approximately 650 feet of a new 4-inch plastic main extension from the existing 4-inch plastic main in Williams Street going on to Broadway and to the service location in Medford Street.

[Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DigSafe.

[Falco]: It shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Falco]: Medford Street was rebuilt within the last five.

[Falco]: years and is restricted from receiving a SOP without direct approval from the Commissioner of Public Works.

[Falco]: At a minimum, the SOP application must include a street restoration plan for review and approval.

[Falco]: At a minimum, the street restoration plan must include curb-to-curb paving.

[Falco]: The SOP application must also include a traffic management plan.

[Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances are adversely impacted.

[Falco]: The National Grid shall ensure that all sewer water and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Falco]: Any disturbed concrete sidewalk panels shall be replaced in kind.

[Falco]: Asphalt must be replaced with asphalt.

[Falco]: There are multiple broken concrete panels clustered at the vicinity of the point of entry for the gas service.

[Falco]: This cluster should be replaced as part of the project.

[Falco]: Number four, the sidewalk and street restoration shall be done in consultation with the engineering division and per the requirements of the approved street opening permit.

[Falco]: Number five, pavement markings including the hatch pattern must be restored.

[Falco]: Number six, the project site must be swept daily.

[Falco]: It shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[Falco]: And those are the, basically that was approved and those were the conditions that were put forth by our city engineer.

[Falco]: So this here project has been approved by our city engineer with the following conditions.

[Falco]: I'm just going to read the conditions, then I know a number of councilors have questions, and there are quite a few conditions.

[Falco]: The engineer division recommends that the grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[Falco]: These conditions include minor revisions to vault locations and conduit runs.

[Falco]: Prior to issuance of a street opening permit, Comcast must submit a revised plan with the city clerk and engineering division for record.

[Falco]: Number one, the grant of location is limited to the conduit, vaults, handholds, and service conduit as described in the petition.

[Falco]: High Street, starting at the existing conduit located in front of number 84 High Street, excavating to place two

[Falco]: Let's see, four-inch PVC conduits, 1,094 plus or minus, and two three-by-three manholes in nine two-by-three vaults.

[Falco]: Bradley Road, starting at the proposed manhole and the sidewalk, excavating place two.

[Falco]: 4-inch PVC conduits, 170 foot plus or minus to utility pole number 5516-1.

[Falco]: Main Street, starting at the proposed vault number 9.

[Falco]: On High Street, excavating to place 2.

[Falco]: 4-inch PVC conduits, 115 feet plus or minus to proposed vault number 10.

[Falco]: Continuing.

[Falco]: From vault number 10 excavating to place one four inch PVC conduit, 155 feet, to number 32 Main Street, Riverside Avenue.

[Falco]: Starting at proposed vault number 10 on Main Street, excavating to place two four inch PVC conduits, 240 feet, plus or minus to number one, Salem Street.

[Falco]: And proposing to place a two by three vault,

[Falco]: over the existing conduit located in the sidewalk.

[Falco]: Number two, the plan indicates that conflicts with other utilities may result in a change in location of conduits and structures.

[Falco]: Changes in locations of conduit runs or structures by more than two feet requires the approval of a revised G.O.L.

[Falco]: Changes to structure locations less than two feet must be approved by the city engineer.

[Falco]: The note on the plan must be revised to indicate this information.

[Falco]: Number three, before starting work, the contractor must notify dig safe and must obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[Falco]: This project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Falco]: The SOP application must include a street restoration plan and traffic management plan for review and approval by the engineering division.

[Falco]: Sea surface restoration requirements below the TMP must

[Falco]: be prepared and stamped by a licensed professional engineer and must include accommodations for pedestrians, bicycles, and vehicles.

[Falco]: Number four, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances are adversely impacted.

[Falco]: Comcast must ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Falco]: Number five, Comcast must submit a project

[Falco]: schedule and sequence plan to the engineering division for review and approval.

[Falco]: The project shall be limited to one crew.

[Falco]: Number six, sections of work may be required to take place at night due to daytime traffic volumes.

[Falco]: This must be coordinated with the Medford Police Department to minimize disruptions in traffic.

[Falco]: in the interest of public safety.

[Falco]: Number seven, Comcast must submit the communications and notification plan to the mayor's office for review and approval.

[Falco]: It must include timely notifications to impacted business and residents.

[Falco]: Number eight, the plan indicates a riverfront area jurisdictional line.

[Falco]: Comcast must review this line in consultation with the Medford Conservation Commission.

[Falco]: Riverfront areas are wetland resources and are under the jurisdiction of the Medford Conservation Commission.

[Falco]: If an order of conditions is required, it must be issued prior to the release of ASOP.

[Falco]: Nine, copies of the MWRA 8M permit must be submitted to the engineering division with the SOP application.

[Falco]: Ten, Comcast may have abandoned utilities in Medford.

[Falco]: A map showing the location of Comcast abandoned utilities in Medford must be submitted to the engineering division for record.

[Falco]: Number 11, as part of the City of Medford COVID-19 emergency response, there are Jersey barriers set up on High Street and outdoor dining space.

[Falco]: If any of these barriers must be temporarily removed, this work must be coordinated with the associated restaurants to take place at a time that minimizes impact to these restaurants.

[Falco]: If this work must take place during business hours, there must be paid restitution.

[Falco]: Number 12,

[Falco]: The contractor must submit a COVID-19 work safety plan with the SOP application.

[Falco]: The plan is subject to approval by the Board of Health and must be approved before the release of the permit.

[Falco]: Number 13, the sidewalk and street restoration must be done in consultation with the engineering division in per the requirements of the approved SOP.

[Falco]: Cement concrete sidewalks must be replaced in kind and cleanly cut at the control joints to extend

[Falco]: To extents described below, the bituminous concrete pavement over the trench must be milled and overlaid.

[Falco]: In the extents described below and approved by the engineering division, the brick-stamped cement concrete edging shall be replaced in kind.

[Falco]: A, in general, sidewalk replacements must include panels from

[Falco]: Curb to back of existing sidewalk or right of way line.

[Falco]: Expansion joints must be placed at several intervals less than or equal to 30 feet.

[Falco]: Less than or equal to 30 feet.

[Falco]: Control joints must be placed to best meet and match existing conditions at the intervals no greater than six feet.

[Falco]: Hybrids, utility poles, and driveway aprons must receive expansion joints to isolate.

[Falco]: All joints must meet ADA requirements.

[Falco]: B, Riverside Avenue must be resurfaced curb to curb to an offset of at least, to an offset at least 10 feet.

[Falco]: to the eastern trench limits.

[Falco]: C, there are at least two monitoring wells in the east gutter of Main Street near the intersection of Riverside Avenue.

[Falco]: These wells are related to a remediation project and must be protected.

[Falco]: The location in the gutter also conflicts with the granite curb concrete backing.

[Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the run of conduit be placed in the sidewalk to avoid these wells and to avoid undermining the curbing.

[Falco]: D, the trench surface restoration crossing Clippership Drive must be resurfaced at an offset of at least 10 feet from the trench limits.

[Falco]: E, the conduit on the south side of Clippership Drive must be placed beneath the sidewalk.

[Falco]: The landscaped area is reserved for tree growth.

[Falco]: F, the trench surface restoration crossing Main Street must be resurfaced to an offset of at least 10 feet from the trench limits.

[Falco]: G, the trench surface restoration on High Street and Bradley Road must be curb to curb.

[Falco]: H, Vault 9 appears to be located in a sidewalk panel that includes a portion of a pedestrian ramp that is in poor condition.

[Falco]: The restoration must include a new pedestrian ramp that meets ADA requirements.

[Falco]: The vault cover must be located within the ramp wings and level landings.

[Falco]: The vault must be located within the furniture zone if possible.

[Falco]: The pedestrian ramps at the opposite sides of the crossing must also be replaced and meet ADA requirements.

[Falco]: I, a sidewalk panel adjacent to vault 8 on the west side is cracked.

[Falco]: It must be replaced.

[Falco]: The asphalt patch adjacent to the cracked panel must be replaced with cement concrete sidewalk.

[Falco]: J, vault 6 is located in an existing asphalt patch.

[Falco]: The asphalt must be replaced with cement concrete.

[Falco]: The cement concrete panels adjacent to the location are cracked and must be replaced.

[Falco]: K, manhole 2, an associated excavation and conduit

[Falco]: will disturb the existing pedestrian ramp on the west side of Bradley Road.

[Falco]: The main old cover must not be located within a ramp, wings, or level landings.

[Falco]: The new ramp placed as part of the restoration must be ADA compliant.

[Falco]: The pedestrian ramp at the east side of the crossing must be replaced to meet ADA requirements.

[Falco]: L, fault five is located adjacent to an asphalt patch that must be replaced with cement concrete sidewalk.

[Falco]: The sidewalk panels adjacent to this fault are cracked and must be replaced.

[Falco]: M, vault four is located adjacent to the building.

[Falco]: The vault must be relocated to the furniture zone if feasible.

[Falco]: The adjacent asphalt patch must be replaced with cement concrete sidewalk.

[Falco]: And vault three appears to conflict with a city trash barrel.

[Falco]: The vault must be removed or a new trash barrel location coordinated with the DPW.

[Falco]: The adjacent sidewalk panel at the street light in the adjacent panel near the building are cracked.

[Falco]: It must be replaced.

[Falco]: Vault three must be located in the furniture zone if feasible.

[Falco]: O, vault 2 must be located in the furniture zone if feasible.

[Falco]: P, vault 1 must be located in the furniture zone if feasible.

[Falco]: The adjacent panel in poor condition must be replaced.

[Falco]: Q, the surface conduit for 81 High Street passes under damaged curb.

[Falco]: The damaged curb must not be reused.

[Falco]: The sidewalk panels adjacent to the conduit line are cracked, it's spalling, it must be replaced.

[Falco]: 20-541 communications from the mayor September 3rd 2020 the electronic delivery to the Honorable President members of the Medford City Council City of Medford Massachusetts 02155 regarding the proposed ordinance historic district dear Mr. President and members of the City Council I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approved the following amendments to the City of Medford revised ordinances

[Falco]: ordinances entitled Historic District Commission, Article 3, Section 48 through 51 as described below.

[Falco]: The amendments clarify the ordinance to delineate the previously approved districts and at the request of the Methodist Historical District Commission, create a new single parcel historic district.

[Falco]: at 16 Foster Court.

[Falco]: By way of background, Section 48 through 51 presently states under the authority of Master M.G.L.A.

[Falco]: Chapter 40, Section 3, there is hereby established a Hillside Avenue Historic District and Moms Simmons Historic District bounded as respectively shown on the map entitled Historic Avenue Historic District.

[Falco]: and Monson's Historic District, which are on file in the city clerk's office and made part of this article by reference.

[Falco]: Pursuant to Mass General Law, Chapter 40C, Section 3, the attached report and request has been transmitted to the Community Development Board for the concurrent review.

[Falco]: The matter is scheduled to be taken up at the Community Development Board on September 16th, 2020.

[Falco]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn mayor.

[Falco]: By being ordained by the City Council of the City of Medford as follows, Amendment 1, Section 48 through 51A of the Revised Ordinance, City of Medford, Massachusetts, is hereby amended to read as follows.

[Falco]: Under the authority of MGLA Chapter 40, Section 3, the following historic districts bound respectively

[Falco]: and which are on file in the city clerk's office and made a part of the article by reference are hereby established.

[Falco]: Number one, Hillside Avenue Historic District.

[Falco]: Number two, Marm Simmons Historic District Amendment.

[Falco]: Two, section 48-51A of the revised ordinances, City of Manfred, Massachusetts, as amended in section one, is hereby further amended to read as follows.

[Falco]: Under the authority of MGLA,

[Falco]: Chapter 40C, Section 3, the following historic districts, bounded respectfully, and which are on file in the City Clerk's Office and made a part of this article of reference are hereby established.

[Falco]: Number one, Hillside Avenue Historic District.

[Falco]: Two, Marm Simmons Historic District.

[Falco]: Three, 16 Foster Court Historic District.

[Falco]: Method Historic District Commission and Method Historical Commission report on 16 Foster Court.

[Falco]: We also received the communication from the, let's see, from the CD board to John C. Falco, Jr., President, Method City Council, Adam Herdeby, City Clerk, from Andre LaRue, Chairman.

[Falco]: It's dated September 18th, 2020.

[Falco]: regarding the proposed local historic district at the Haskell-Cutter House 16 Foster Court, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Falco]: At its meeting on September 16, 2020, the Community Development Board voted to make no recommendation on the proposed local historic district at the Haskell-Cutter House 16 Foster Court, Medford.

[Falco]: but encourages the parties involved to pursue preservation of the historic structure either on this site or another site.

[Falco]: During the robust discussion, board members expressed their desire to work with the Historic District Commission to prioritize conservation properties for future districts, find additional ways of celebrating Medford shipbuilding history, and support a citywide evaluation of the city's historic assets.

[Falco]: Thank you for the opportunity to review this matter.

[Falco]: Communications from the mayor.

[Falco]: And this is 20-566.

[Falco]: September 17, 2020, the electronic delivery to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, regarding Home Rule Petition Charter Commission.

[Falco]: Dear Mr. President and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approve the following Home Rule Petition and transmit to the General Court for their consideration.

[Falco]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Falco]: An act authorizing the election of a charter commission in the city of Medford.

[Falco]: Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives and General Court assembled and by the authority of the same as follows.

[Falco]: Section one, notwithstanding the provisions of chapter 43B of the general laws of the provisions of any general law, special law or regulation to the contrary, the city of Medford.

[Falco]: The city the city of Medford City Council shall at the first regular city regular city election or a fogging up City election or early occurring special election held

[Falco]: On or after the 60th day following the effective date of this act, by order, provide for submission to the voters of the city the question of adopting or revising a charter and for the election of a nine member charter commission.

[Falco]: Section two, other than as set forth herein, the provisions of chapter 43B of the general laws shall be applicable to the nomination and election of charter commissioners and to the duties and responsibilities of the city and the charter commission elected here under.

[Falco]: Section three, this act shall take effect upon its passage.

[Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: Okay, thank you, Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: We have Jackie Peeks, who is representing the administration tonight.

[Falco]: Notice of a public hearing, 19-481.

[Falco]: Public hearing notice, amendment to chapter 94, zoning.

[Falco]: Revised ordinances of the City of Medford, Medford City Council, September 22nd, 2020.

[Falco]: The Medford City Council will conduct a public hearing on Tuesday, September 22, 2020 at 7 p.m.

[Falco]: via Zoom remote video conferencing relative to a petition on Council Paper 19-481, Chapter 94, Zoning, Section 94-2, Definitions.

[Falco]: Definitions is proposed to be amended to add definitions for brewery, tasting room, tap room, barrel, and brew pub.

[Falco]: Section 94-148, table of use regulations is proposed to be amended by adding use 35B, brewery, which will be allowable by right in C2IOA.

[Falco]: In the C1 district, breweries operating with seven barrels or under will be allowable by right.

[Falco]: If breweries operating with more than seven barrels will be allowable by special permit board of appeals.

[Falco]: The full text of the amendment may be viewed in the office of the city clerk, city hall, room 103, or on the city's website at http://www.methodma.org, departments, community development, by clicking on the current CD board filings.

[Falco]: A Zoom link for this meeting will be posted no later than Friday, September 18th, 2020.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: So we did receive a paper here from the CD board.

[Falco]: And I'm just going to read it quick so everybody can.

[Falco]: Listen, it's from the Community Development Board to John C. Falco, Jr., President, Medford City Council, and to Adam Hurtubise, City Clerk, from Andre LaRue, Chairman, dated September 8, 2020, regarding Council Paper 20-481, proposed amendment to Chapter 94, zoning to add definitions and an additional line brewery to the table of use regulations.

[Falco]: Following a duly advertised public hearing conducted on September 16, 2020, the Community Development Board voted to recommend that the Medford City Council adopt the proposed amendment to Chapter 94 zoning, as well as in Council Paper 20-481.

[Falco]: Board members strongly supported the proposal to allow breweries and brew pubs to operate in the city.

[Falco]: Furthermore, given the fact that some other breweries in the region have become social gathering spots, the board respectfully suggests including the following language to provide additional flexibility to their operations.

[Falco]: Add the following after the last line in the definition for brewery.

[Falco]: The facility may also provide food that is produced on site,

[Falco]: produced off-site or produced with food trucks that are located on-site.

[Falco]: Thank you for your consideration of this recommendation.

[Falco]: Andrea LaRue, Chairman, and that was CC to Brianna Lungo, current Mayor, and to Kimberly Scanlon, City Solicitor, and to Paul Moki, the Building Commissioner.

[Falco]: The 24th regular meeting of the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[Falco]: I am present.

[Falco]: All seven members are present.

[Falco]: At this point in time, I ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[Falco]: This is being broadcast live on channel 22 for Comcast and channel 43 on Verizon.

[Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18 and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing

[Falco]: strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Falco]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Falco]: I want to thank everyone for attending tonight.

[Falco]: We have a number of hearings tonight.

[Falco]: The proposed amendment would require a special permit from the city council, SPC, requiring that at least 25% of the total gross floor area of the development contain non-residential uses permitted by right, of which are authorized pursuant to a special permit in the underlying zoning district where relevant overlying zoning

[Falco]: where relevant overlying zoning districts.

[Falco]: 20-478, notice of a public hearing.

[Falco]: Petition for grant of location, Tufts University, Medford, Massachusetts, electrical transmission line.

[Falco]: Medford, Massachusetts City Clerk's Office, you are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, a public hearing will be given via Zoom at 7 p.m.

[Falco]: on Tuesday, July 28th on a petition of Tufts University for permission to install an electrical transmission line beneath Boston Avenue near the intersection of College Avenue and to locate poles, wires, and fixtures, including the necessary sustaining and protecting fixtures along and across the public way herein named

[Falco]: said poll locations to be located substantially in accordance with the revised plan marked Boston Avenue.

[Falco]: Menford, Massachusetts will be filed in the Office of the City Clerk on June 4, 2020.

[Falco]: A Zoom link for this meeting will be provided no later than Friday, July 24, 2020.

[Falco]: Wherefore, it prays that after due notice and hearing, as provided by law, it be granted a location for and permission to erect and maintain poles and wires, together with such as standing and protecting fixtures as it may find necessary, said electrical transmission line be erected substantially in accordance with the revised plan marked Boston Ave, Medford, Massachusetts, and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 103,

[Falco]: 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[Falco]: Also, for permission to lay and maintain underground laterals, cables, and wires in the above or intersecting public ways for the purpose of making connections with such poles in buildings as each of said petitioners may desire for distributing purposes.

[Falco]: The following are the streets and highways referred to.

[Falco]: Boston Avenue in the vicinity of the new power plant building

[Falco]: near the intersection of College Avenue.

[Falco]: Location approximately as shown on plan filed in the office of the city clerk.

[Falco]: This was approved by the city engineer with the following conditions.

[Falco]: The engineer division recommends that the grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[Falco]: One, the grant of location, GOL, is limited to approximately 60 feet of electrical transmission main described in the GOL document as follows.

[Falco]: Number two, excavation of Boston Avenue is an installation and maintenance of eight by six underground electrical conduits and wires together with such sustaining and protecting fixtures as may be necessary for the transmission of electricity under and across Boston Avenue, a public way approximately 500 feet north of the center line of the intersection of Boston Avenue and College Avenue, said location request.

[Falco]: touched athletic utility district, Medford, Massachusetts, and filled, filed in the office of the city clerk the plan.

[Falco]: The work consists of installing approximately 55 linear feet of electrical duct bank to an electric manhole as

[Falco]: shown on the plan and to connect to conduits of petitioner's property and property of the Massachusetts Bay Transportation.

[Falco]: Number three, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Falco]: The SOP application must include a proposal for temporary and permanent street restoration to be considered as a condition.

[Falco]: Please see additional comments below on street restoration.

[Falco]: The SOP application must also include a traffic management plan.

[Falco]: Number four, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or other appearances are adversely impacted.

[Falco]: Tufts shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Falco]: Any disturbed concrete sidewalk panels shall be replaced in kind.

[Falco]: Asphalt must be replaced with asphalt.

[Falco]: Five, the sidewalk and street temporary and permit restoration shall be done in consultation with the engineering division and per the requirements.

[Falco]: of an approved street opening permit.

[Falco]: The recent resurfacing of Boston Avenue stopped short of this location due to the anticipated and ongoing construction related to both Tufts University projects and the Green Line Extension project.

[Falco]: Also, the City of Medford intends to add a pedestrian crossing in this vicinity using funds obtained from the MBTA related to mitigation for the GLX project.

[Falco]: The engineering division recommends that in lieu of performing final street restoration, a contribution be negotiated and agreed upon with the city engineer that approximates the construction cost value of finished street restoration.

[Falco]: The cost should take into consideration.

[Falco]: in consideration roadway mill and overlay restoration with a curb-to-curb offset of 25 feet, including setting curb stones and sidewalk restoration and mill and overlay restoration encompassing Tufts University utility patches from the intersection of College Avenue to the limits of Dolan Hall.

[Falco]: This contribution will go towards final resurfacing of this section of Boston Avenue.

[Falco]: This will provide a consistent final pavement surface along this section of Boston Avenue.

[Falco]: Number six, pavement markings must be restored.

[Falco]: Number seven, the project site must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[Falco]: Number eight, a copy of the MWRA permit and associated plans must be submitted to the engineering division prior to releasing a street opening permit.

[Falco]: Number nine, the plan indicates open trench construction

[Falco]: There is existing concrete barrier structure and cable guardrail that must be removed for the installation of the transmission line.

[Falco]: These two elements should not be replaced.

[Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the petitioner coordinates sidewalk surface restoration with the Greenline Extension Project as there is sidewalk scope for that project on the east side of Boston Avenue.

[Falco]: Any temporary restoration must meet accessibility standards.

[Falco]: The sidewalk on the west side is likely to remain

[Falco]: and should be permanently restored to concrete upon completion of the crossing.

[Falco]: Approved by the Superintendent of Wires, call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations and or aids.

[Falco]: Plans can be reviewed at the City Clerk's Office, 781-393-2425, Adam L. Hurtubise's City Clerk.

[Falco]: I declare this public hearing open, open to those in favor of the petition.

[Falco]: Is there anyone that would like to speak in favor of the petition?

[Falco]: Rocco, I'm trying to unmute you now.

[Falco]: Oh, there we go.

[Falco]: Notice of a public hearing, legal notice 20-479, petition for grant of location, National Grid Incorporated of North Andover, Massachusetts, and Verizon New England Incorporated, Medford, Massachusetts, City Clerk's Office.

[Falco]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, a public hearing will be given via Zoom at 7 p.m.

[Falco]: on Tuesday, July 28, 2020,

[Falco]: on a joint petition of National Grid Incorporated and Verizon New England Incorporated for permission to locate poles, wires, and fixtures, including the necessary sustaining and protecting fixtures along and across the public way here and after name to be located substantially in accordance with the plan marked number 29567848

[Falco]: Winthrop Street, Medford, Massachusetts, April 4, 2020, and filed in the office of the city clerk on May 11, 2020.

[Falco]: The Zoom link for this meeting will be provided no later than Friday, July 24, 2020.

[Falco]: We are for a praise that after due notice and hearing as provided by law, it be granted a location for a permission to erect and maintain poles and wires gathered with such sustaining and protecting fixtures as it may find necessary.

[Falco]: Set electrical transmission line to be erected substantially in accordance with the plan marked number 29567848.

[Falco]: and available for inspection in the Office of the City Clerk, Method City Hall, Room 103-85 George P. Hassett Drive, Method, MA 02155.

[Falco]: Also, for permission to lay and maintain underground laterals, cables, and wires in the above

[Falco]: or intersecting public ways for the purpose of making connections with such poles and buildings as each of said petitioners may desire for distributing purposes.

[Falco]: The following are the streets and highways referred to.

[Falco]: Winthrop Street National Grid to relocate one J-O pole on Winthrop Street near Victory Park beginning at a point approximately 25 feet southwest of the center line of the intersection of Winthrop Street near Victory Park.

[Falco]: Relocate number 265 on Winthrop Street, seven feet away to the

[Falco]: Package of the sidewalk for the installation of Eversource facilities.

[Falco]: No tree removal shall be required.

[Falco]: Location approximately as shown on the plan filed in the office of the city clerk.

[Falco]: This was approved by the chief engineer with the following conditions.

[Falco]: Number one, the grant of location are limited to the relocation of one joint owned pole in the underground services associated with the pole relocation.

[Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other apparatances are adversely impacted.

[Falco]: National Group shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Falco]: Any disturbed concrete sidewalk panels shall be replaced in kind.

[Falco]: Asphalt must be replaced with asphalt.

[Falco]: Number four, the project site must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[Falco]: Number five, the proposed work is located adjacent to Victory Park and its access points.

[Falco]: National Green must coordinate with the Metro DPW Parks Division to maintain access to the park and mitigate impacts to the use of the park.

[Falco]: Number six, the work is close to existing bollards and the plan does not indicate removal or replacement of bollards.

[Falco]: The bollards shall remain in place.

[Falco]: Number seven,

[Falco]: There are multiple trees that have canopy that will be impacted by the relocation of the associated overhead wires.

[Falco]: The contractor must coordinate any required tree trimming prior to start of work with the Method DPW tree warden.

[Falco]: Number eight, the new pole location appears to be within the root zone of the adjacent tree.

[Falco]: Protection measures for the tree roots must be coordinated with the Method DPW tree warden.

[Falco]: Number nine, shutdowns associated with the service transfer for the pump station must be coordinated with the station owner.

[Falco]: This is approved by the superintendent of wires.

[Falco]: Call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations, aids.

[Falco]: That's from Adam L. Hurtubise.

[Falco]: Plans can be reviewed or viewed in the city clerk's office at 781-393-2425.

[Falco]: on Tuesday, July 28, 2020, on a petition of Comcast Cable Communications, LLC.

[Falco]: Okay.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: So at this point, I would declare the public hearing open.

[Falco]: Actually, before I move any further, I just wanted to note that this year has been approved by the chief engineer with the following conditions.

[Falco]: The engineering division recommends that this grain of location be approved with the following conditions.

[Falco]: Number one, the grain of location is limited to approximately 52 feet of conduit.

[Falco]: Proposed vault and service conduit as described in the petition.

[Falco]: Starting at the existing Comcast vault excavating to place two four-inch PVC conduits

[Falco]: 52 plus or minus to a proposed two-by-three vault in the sidewalk.

[Falco]: From the newly placed vault excavating to a place one four-inch PVC conduit, three plus or minus and continue on to private property.

[Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[Falco]: The project must obtain a

[Falco]: Street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Falco]: At a minimum, the street opening permit application must include a street restoration plan and traffic management plan for review and approval.

[Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances are adversely impacted.

[Falco]: Comcast shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Falco]: Number four, the sidewalk and street restoration shall be done in consultation with the engineering division in further requirements of an approved street opening permit.

[Falco]: This must include a site inspection with the permit officer to determine the extent of pavement restoration.

[Falco]: The concrete sidewalk must be replaced in kind and cleanly cut at the control joints.

[Falco]: The bituminous concrete pavement over the trench shall be milled and overlaid to an offset approved by the engineering division.

[Falco]: The brick-stamped concrete edging shall be replaced in kind.

[Falco]: Number five, pavement markings- President, if I could stop you on that point for a moment?

[Falco]: Yes.

[Falco]: Mr. Flewellen, could you comment on that, please?

[Falco]: Number five, pavement markings must be restored.

[Falco]: Number six, the project site must be scrubbed daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[Falco]: Number seven, Riverside Avenue is a highly traveled roadway for vehicles as well as pedestrians.

[Falco]: A detailed TMP must be submitted to the engineering division for review and approved prior to receiving a street opening permit.

[Falco]: The TMP must include accommodations for pedestrians

[Falco]: in addition to vehicles.

[Falco]: Number eight, the plan does not indicate drain lines or laterals.

[Falco]: Drainage pipes beneath the conduit must be replaced.

[Falco]: Number nine, the conduit must cross MWRA infrastructure.

[Falco]: Copies of the MWRA permit must be submitted to the engineering division prior to releasing a street opening permit approved by the superintendent of wires.

[Falco]: The motion is tabled.

[Falco]: 19-481, July 23rd, 2022, Brianna Lugo, current mayor.

[Falco]: uh, from Kimberly M. Scalen, acting city solicitor regarding council paper 19-481.

[Falco]: On June 9, 2020, the Medford City Council requested that the proposed brewery ordinance have the following amendments made there too.

[Falco]: At the consultation with the building commissioner, Paul Mokey, I have drafted the amendments.

[Falco]: I respectfully request that this paper is sent to the Medford City Council.

[Falco]: respectfully submitted Kimberley M. Scanlon.

[Falco]: An ordinance amending Article 1, Chapter 94 of the revised ordinances of the City of Medford.

[Falco]: Be it ordained by the City Council of the City of Medford that Article 1, Chapter 94 of the revised of the revised ordinance of the City of Medford as most recently amended is hereby further amended by the addition of two new definitions in Section 94-2 and

[Falco]: adding an additional line called brewery to the principal uses set forth in the table of use regulations in section 94-148.

[Falco]: The following two definitions are hereby added to section 94-2 entitled definitions.

[Falco]: Brewery means an establishment primarily engaged in the production and distribution of beer, ale, and other malt beverages, which may include accessory uses such as tours of the brewery, retail sales, and or on-site consumption of the products

[Falco]: For example, a tap room or tasting room.

[Falco]: The facility shall hold the appropriate Commonwealth of Massachusetts brewery license, as well as any required pouring license approved by the local licensing authority.

[Falco]: This facility may host marketing events, special events, and brewery tours.

[Falco]: The facility may only sell beverages produced by and commercial goods branded by the brewery.

[Falco]: Tasting room tap room means a room attached to a brewery that allows patrons to sample or consume bear, ale, or other malt beverages that are produced on site in accordance with general law chapter 138.

[Falco]: Barrel means a container, usually cylindrical in nature, used for the storage of a malt beverage with a capacity of not more than 31 gallons.

[Falco]: A line number 35B entitled brewery is hereby added to the principal uses set

[Falco]: fourth in the table of use regulations in section 94-148 as follows.

[Falco]: Table of use regulations in off-street parking and loading requirements.

[Falco]: Let's see, so use brewery.

[Falco]: This is communications from city officers and employees.

[Falco]: Actually, yeah, so I'm sorry.

[Falco]: So it's not allowed in SF1, SF2, GR&O, Apartment 1, Apartment 2, Apartment 3.

[Falco]: C1, yes for breweries operating with seven barrels or under.

[Falco]: SPA, for breweries operating with more than seven barrels.

[Falco]: C2, it's allowable.

[Falco]: I, industrial, it is allowable.

[Falco]: O, yes.

[Falco]: MUZ, yes.

[Falco]: Parking 350.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Paris.

[Falco]: Clerk, Hurtubise?

[Falco]: That's an amendment by Councilor Morell.

[Falco]: Yes.

[Falco]: Okay.

[Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Morell.

[Falco]: Questions from the councilors?

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Falco]: Let's see, any other questions from the council?

[Falco]: Comments?

[Falco]: Any comments from the public?

[Falco]: Max, name and address the record, please.

[Falco]: Thank you, Max.

[Falco]: Let's see, we have a number of people that want to speak.

[Falco]: 20-472 Memorandum to President John Falco and members of the Medford City Council.

[Falco]: CC registrar vote is from Adam Hurtubise, City Clerk, regarding Ward 3, Precinct 1 polling location, July 23, 2020.

[Falco]: This is a follow-up paper to 20-472 from last month, as I reported in June.

[Falco]: The former Lawrence Memorial Hospital site will not be available as a polling location for the September-November elections because of the ongoing construction and because of COVID-19 concerns.

[Falco]: When I became aware that the LMH campus would not be available as a polling location, I began working identifying a new potential polling location for Ward 3, Precinct 1.

[Falco]: I sought guidance from the Election Division of the Office of Secretary of the Commonwealth on designation of a new polling place.

[Falco]: I reached out to the Commander Richard Martin of the American Legion post at 321 Winthrop Street.

[Falco]: Commander Martin graciously volunteered the Legion Post as a polling place for both- Mr. President, move for the Reader's Digest version.

[Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Knight to get a brief synopsis from our City Clerk.

[Falco]: City Clerk, could you please give us a brief synopsis of the paper?

[Falco]: Okay, on the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by Councilor Bears, Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[Falco]: The 16th regular meeting of the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[Falco]: Clerk, please call the roll.

[Falco]: Present.

[Falco]: All seven members are present.

[Falco]: At this time, I'd ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag

[Falco]: This meeting is being broadcast live on Channel 22 Comcast and Channel 43 Verizon.

[Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions in the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Falco]: No in-person attendance or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Falco]: In the event that we are able to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting,

[Falco]: Hearings 20-343 Legal Notice City of Medford Five-Year Consolidated Plan 2020 Annual Public Action Plan Revised Public Hearing.

[Falco]: This is a public hearing.

[Falco]: A virtual public hearing via Zoom will be held by the Medford City Council on Tuesday, May 12, 2020 at 7 p.m.

[Falco]: The purpose of the public hearing will be to invite the general public and representatives of public service agencies to express comments regarding the city's five-year consolidated plan and annual actual plan for community development and planning.

[Falco]: The actual plan contains the proposed use of community development block grant CDBG funds for programming in 2020, which extends

[Falco]: from July 1st, 2020 through June 30th, 2021.

[Falco]: The consolidated plan includes broad goals and objectives to address priority needs with resources available from HUD, including a five-year strategy for use of CDBG funding for the years 2020 through 2024.

[Falco]: The Office of Community Development will be requesting that the Medford City Council authorize Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, official representative of the City of Medford, to submit the 2020 through 2024 Consolidated Plan and 2020 Annual Action Plan application for funds in all assurances and certifications to the U.S.

[Falco]: Department of Housing and Urban Development.

[Falco]: The city's applying for $1,574,868 in CDBG funds.

[Falco]: Call 781-393-2501 for any accommodations slash aids.

[Falco]: TDD 781-393-2516.

[Falco]: Medford is an EEOAA 504 employer.

[Falco]: At this point, I declare the public hearing open to those in favor of the petition.

[Falco]: Is there anyone here that is in favor of the petition?

[Falco]: Okay, if you could please have your name and address for the record.

[Falco]: Okay.

[Falco]: At this point, is there anyone else in favor of the

[Falco]: Is there anyone else here in favor that would like to speak at this point in time?

[Falco]: Okay.

[Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, has anything come in through email?

[Falco]: Okay.

[Falco]: At this point, I declare this portion of the hearing closed.

[Falco]: Anyone in opposition of the petition?

[Falco]: Is there anyone here tonight that is opposition to the petition?

[Falco]: Yes.

[Falco]: Are you in opposition to the petition, miss?

[Falco]: Oh, no answer.

[Falco]: No worries at all.

[Falco]: Is there anyone in opposition of the petition?

[Falco]: Clerk, Hurtubise.

[Falco]: Any communication or email from anyone in opposition?

[Falco]: Seeing and hearing none, I declare this portion of the hearing closed.

[Falco]: Alicia, if you'd like to present now or make your presentation, please, you can do that right now.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Move for approval, Mr. President

[Falco]: On the motion of councilor Knight. Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: On the motion council Knight, seconded by Councilor Marks, Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Any other questions from the council?

[Falco]: Okay.

[Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, any questions that have come in through email?

[Falco]: Communications from the mayor, 20-355.

[Falco]: Dear Council President Falco,

[Falco]: and honorable members of the Medford City Council.

[Falco]: As you are aware, the city is working in coordination with MassDOT to plan for safe routes to school project for the Brooks Elementary School.

[Falco]: The project involves improvements to sidewalks that directly abut private residential parcels.

[Falco]: The federal funding granted for this project requires that the right-of-way be in complete ownership and physical control of the city.

[Falco]: The survey prepared

[Falco]: for the project identify 12 private properties that contain public infrastructure or require a temporary construction easement.

[Falco]: In order to meet the requirements of the projects, permanent easements will alter the High Street, Mystic Street, and Walcott Street layouts to encompass the public infrastructure in temporary easements with

[Falco]: will facilitate construction of sidewalks.

[Falco]: The written offer was sent to the 12 property owners via certified mail on April 2, 2020, and Tim McGibbon, City Engineer, has been in contact with each owner to address concerns throughout this process, starting from the initial contact letter back in December 2019.

[Falco]: easements were appraised by a certified general appraiser and those appraisals were reviewed by a certified general review appraiser to establish just compensation for the easements.

[Falco]: I respectfully request that the city council vote to approve the attached order of taking associated with these easements at your regular May 12, 2020 meeting and therefore approve

[Falco]: the alternations of High Street, Mystic Street, and Walcott Street.

[Falco]: The alternations of High Street, Mystic Street, and Walcott Street are approved by the Mayor and recommended to the City Council by the Community Development Board via unanimous vote on March 25, 2020.

[Falco]: Mr. McGibbon will be in attendance to answer any questions on this matter.

[Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Falco]: Additional documents may be inspected in the office of the city clerk, Bedford City Hall, Bedford, Massachusetts.

[Falco]: Okay, let's see.

[Falco]: Motions, orders, and resolutions.

[Falco]: 20-344 offered by Councilor Knight and Vice President Caraviello.

[Falco]: Whereas the question was raised at a recent meeting by the Zoning Court of Appeals as to whether or not experiences are authorized in the City of Medford.

[Falco]: And whereas on July 19, 2016, the City of the Medford City Council approved paper 166-586.

[Falco]: which requested a written legal opinion from the city solicitor as to whether or not use variances are authorized in the city of Medford.

[Falco]: And whereas, on August 12, 2016, the city solicitor provided the requested legal opinion to the city council, which determined use variances are authorized in the city of Medford.

[Falco]: And whereas, this opinion was not challenged by any entity in any legal form.

[Falco]: And whereas, the Medford City Council failed to approve Papers 1-7

[Falco]: and 18-354 seeking the deauthorization of use variances in the City of Medford and whereas on April 24, 2018, the Medford City Council approved

[Falco]: 18-376 in a super majority roll call vote, calling for the adoption of the city solicitor's opinion and authorization to amend the codified ordinances to reflect the finding of his opinion.

[Falco]: And whereas the Medford City Council in the city of Medford is the city of Medford legislative body enabled as the sole authority responsible for the passage of local zoning law, be it resolved that the Medford City Council requests

[Falco]: The city solicitor Scanlon forward to the Zoning Board of Appeals a copy of the solicitor's opinion and other documents deemed necessary at her discretion.

[Falco]: And be it further resolved that the city clerk provide copies of Papers 16-856, 17-007, 18-354, and 18-376 to the Zoning Board of Appeals.

[Falco]: We have further resolved that the Medford City Council respectively requests that the Zoning Board of Appeals acknowledges and affirm by way of roll call vote the following.

[Falco]: Number one, the Zoning Board of Appeals has been provided a copy of the city solicitor's opinion on August 12, 2016, determining use variances are permitted in the city of Medford.

[Falco]: Number two, the Zoning Board of Appeals has been provided with council papers

[Falco]: 16-856, 17-007, 18-354, and 18-376.

[Falco]: Number three, the Zoning Board of Appeals recognizes that the Medford City Council is the City of Medford's legislative body enabled as the sole authority responsible for the passage of local zoning law.

[Falco]: Number four, the Zoning Board of Appeals recognizes that the question as to whether or not use variances are authorized in the City of Medford has been addressed

[Falco]: by way of the August 12, 2016 legal opinion and council passage of paper 18-376.

[Falco]: Number five, the Zoning Board of Appeals recognizes that use variances are authorized in the city of Medford.

[Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Let's see, we have

[Falco]: Communications from the mayor.

[Falco]: June 0-356, joint resolution to petition the federal government for emergency financial relief.

[Falco]: It is hereby resolved by her honor, the mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, the Honorable Medford City Council and the Honorable Medford School Committee that whereas on March 11th, 2020, the World Health Organization designated the COVID-19 outbreak

[Falco]: pandemic health emergency.

[Falco]: And whereas on March 20th, 2020, the governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts issued a declaration of a state of emergency to respond to COVID-19.

[Falco]: And whereas on March 16th, 2020, her honor

[Falco]: The mayor and the Medford Board of Health announced that a local state of emergency exists in the city of Medford.

[Falco]: And whereas the public health crisis has precipitated an economic collapse that has affected every sector of the local, state, and national economies.

[Falco]: Whereas, following this collapse, municipalities across Massachusetts and the United States are facing a fiscal crisis that threatens the ability for cities and towns to deliver critical services to our community.

[Falco]: And whereas, the delivery of these services directly and critically affects the quality of life, safety, education, and health of the Medford community, now therefore be it resolved

[Falco]: that the city of Medford by her honor, the mayor, the honorable city council and the honorable Medford school committee.

[Falco]: Number one, the federal and state governments by and through the city's elected delegations continue engaging with cities and towns to determine budget needs and solutions at the municipal level.

[Falco]: And number two, the federal and state governments consider it an urgent and emergency need to provide adequate financial support to cities and towns to weather the current economic and fiscal crisis in the form of direct stimulus and relief as soon as possible in order to continue to provide the high quality of critical services upon which the Medford community relies.

[Falco]: The original paper filed in the office of the city clerk

[Falco]: Medford City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Falco]: On the motion to approve by Vice President Caraviello, seconded by Councilor Knight, Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[Falco]: Yes.

[Falco]: 70 affirmative, zero in the negative, the motion passes.

[Falco]: Let's see, so we've covered almost it.

[Falco]: We've covered everything, right, Clark-Renovies?

[Falco]: Okay, so reports of committees.

[Falco]: I actually do not have this report in front of me.

[Falco]: Does anyone have, does anyone want to summarize the reports of committees and we can table them to the next meeting?

[Falco]: Motion to table.

[Falco]: Motion to table.

[Falco]: Motion by Councilor Knight to table, seconded by Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: Clerk Urnavis, please call the roll.

[Falco]: Yes, seven affirmative, zero negative.

[Falco]: Those reports are tabled.

[Falco]: Records.

[Falco]: Let's see the records of the meeting of May 5th, 2020 were passed to Councilor Morell.

[Falco]: Councilor Morell, how did you find those records?

[Falco]: I have a motion of Council of Morell to approve the record seconded by Council of Bears.

[Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: Vice President Caraviello.

[Falco]: 70 affirmative, zero negative, the motion passes.

[Falco]: Anything else?

[Falco]: Motion to adjourn.

[Falco]: Second.

[Falco]: On the motion of Vice President Caraviello, seconded by Councilor Knight to adjourn the meeting.

[Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[Falco]: Yes, 70 affirmative, zero negative.

[Falco]: The motion passes, the meeting is adjourned.

[Falco]: See you tomorrow night.

[Falco]: Stay fit and healthy, thank you.

[Falco]: 2-0-089, offered by Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Whereas rule 37 of the Medford City Council reads, insofar as these rules are not statutory sources of origin.

[Falco]: The same may be amended, repealed, or suspended at any meeting by the vote of four councillors, with the exception of papers to be submitted under suspension, which requires two-thirds approval of council.

[Falco]: Any paper to be submitted under suspension shall be read prior to the vote for suspension.

[Falco]: Any suspension of the rules shall be put on paper prior to the vote of the suspension, so all councillors will be fully informed of the matter on which he or she will vote.

[Falco]: If any action is taken inconsistent with these rules, the same shall be construed to have been taken in suspension thereof, provided four counsels concur in such action.

[Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council amend Rule 37 by striking this section in its entirety and replacing it with the following.

[Falco]: Amendment or suspension of the rules.

[Falco]: Insofar as these rules are not statutory sources of origin, the same may be amended, repealed, or suspended at any meeting by the vote of four Councilors, with the exception of papers to be submitted under suspension, which requires two-thirds approval of the counsel.

[Falco]: Any paper to be submitted under suspension shall be read prior to the vote for suspension.

[Falco]: Any suspension of the rule shall be put on paper prior to the vote of the suspension so all consulars will be fully informed of the matter on which he or she will vote.

[Falco]: Number one, papers offered under suspension for immediate consideration shall be limited to public service announcements, condolences, recognition, celebratory, and emergency matters.

[Falco]: Number two any other papers offered at the suspension of the rule shall be tabled following in duck introduction by the sponsor without Further debate and placed on the agenda for the next regular meeting If any action is taken and consistent with these rules the same shall be construed to have been taken in Suspension there are provided for consulars concur in such action Council night

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Falco]: Please have your name and address for the record.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Councilor Peers.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Council members, if you could please have your name and address for the record.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Councilor Caraviello.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Falco]: Councilor Morell.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Morell.

[Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by Councilor Caraviello to move this paper to the city solicitor for legal review.

[Falco]: On that motion, all those in favor?

[Falco]: Aye.

[Falco]: All those opposed?

[Falco]: The motion passes.

[Falco]: 20-090, offered by Council of the Night.

[Falco]: Ordinance establishing an extended illness leave bank.

[Falco]: There shall be an extended illness leave bank for employees of the city who participate therein.

[Falco]: Extended illness advisory board appointment eligibility term.

[Falco]: There shall be an extended illness leave bank advisory board.

[Falco]: This board shall consist of five members that are city employees appointed by the mayor no later than 30 days following passage.

[Falco]: These appointments shall be subject to council approval.

[Falco]: Board members will serve a term of 24 months from the date of council confirmation.

[Falco]: No more than two board members shall be employees at will.

[Falco]: Administration.

[Falco]: The director of personnel shall administer the bank in accord with the rules and regulations established by the Extended Illness Leave Bank Advisory Board and shall be precluded

[Falco]: from serving as a member of this board.

[Falco]: Implementation, participation requirements.

[Falco]: The Extended Illness Advisory Board shall prescribe regulations governing its operation no later than 60 days following confirmation of its fifth member.

[Falco]: The Extended Illness Advisory Board may alter, amend, and update these regulations from time to time thereafter by majority vote of its members.

[Falco]: This shall make one-time investment of 75 leave days to establish the Extended Illness Leave Bank.

[Falco]: Thereafter, any employee of the City who has completed one year of service may participate by donating to said bank any earned sick, personal, or vacation leave time in such amount

[Falco]: with such frequency as said regulation shall permit to maintain a sufficient balance in the bank, but not less frequently than annually.

[Falco]: Upon medical verification pursuant to such regulations, a participating employee with an extended illness who has exhausted all other earned leave

[Falco]: And who has been on leave because of such extended illness for not less than 20 consecutive work days may obtain from said bank additional paid leave or not more than 120 days in any two year period.

[Falco]: Current employees with all other earned leave exhausted who have been on leave because of extended illness shall be eligible to seek benefits from the Extended Illness Leave Bank retroactively to January 1st, 2020.

[Falco]: It shall not be required to donate to said bank any earned sick, personal, or vacation leave time to participate.

[Falco]: Said regulations shall provide safeguards against use of said bank by employees who have improperly used existing sick leave.

[Falco]: The head of each city department shall not less than twice annually provide written notice to each employee of the opportunity to participate in said bank.

[Falco]: Upon receipt of the first such notice, each employee shall be required to sign a form issued by the city indicating that such employee has been informed of the opportunity to participate in said bank.

[Falco]: Nothing contained herein shall affect existing collective bargaining agreements containing provisions relating to the establishment of extended illness leave banks.

[Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli, Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: Thank you Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: Councilor Scarpel.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Falco]: Councilor Caraviello.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Falco]: Councilor Knight, thank you for bringing this forward.

[Falco]: I think it's long overdue.

[Falco]: I'm glad that you brought this forward tonight.

[Falco]: So the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli to move this to Committee of the Whole meeting, and we will invite the city solicitor and the director of personnel.

[Falco]: On that motion, all those in favor?

[Falco]: All those opposed?

[Falco]: The motion passes.

[Falco]: 20-091, offered by Councilor Knight, whereas Rule 18 of the rules of the Medford City Council reads, every order and resolution must be endorsed.

[Falco]: No order or resolution shall be received or acted upon unless endorsed by a member of the Council.

[Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council amend Rule 18 by striking the section and replacing it with the following.

[Falco]: Every order and resolution must be endorsed.

[Falco]: Filing of petitions.

[Falco]: For the purposes of the section, the following definitions shall apply.

[Falco]: Order defined as a local bylaw enacted by the City Council.

[Falco]: Resolution defined as a paper stating an expression of opinion, fact, principle, or purpose.

[Falco]: petition defined as an application requesting council action as required by law.

[Falco]: No order or resolution shall be received or acted upon unless endorsed by a member of the council.

[Falco]: The filing of petitions shall be reserved only for matters requiring council action per law, including but not limited to special permits, grants of location, signed variances, and common vigila licenses.

[Falco]: Only petitions filed

[Falco]: Only petitions filed meeting this criteria shall be assigned a council paper number.

[Falco]: All other petitions filed shall be placed on the public participation portion of the agenda and not assigned a council paper number.

[Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[Falco]: If you could please have your name and address for the record.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by?

[Falco]: I second.

[Falco]: Aye.

[Falco]: All those opposed?

[Falco]: 20-096, offered by Vice President Caraviello.

[Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council sends its deepest and sincere condolences to the family of Tony Anzalone.

[Falco]: On his recent passing, Tony operated Tony's Barbershop in South Medford for 35 years.

[Falco]: Tony was a longtime volunteer at the Medford Senior Center, where he was known for his singing of Frank Sinatra songs at many events.

[Falco]: His presence in our community will be missed.

[Falco]: Before we adjourn for the evening, we did receive a letter from the DCRNF package.

[Falco]: Did everybody get the letter?

[Falco]: Dear City Council, on the date of February 25th, 2020, Medford City Council, City of Medford, 85 George P. Hanson Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[Falco]: Dear City Council of the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation, the DCR is considering the purchase of the fee or lesser interest including but not limited to a

[Falco]: Permanent and perpetual easement in land located in the city of Medford state regulation at 301 CMR 5 1.0 0 Required DCR to provide written notice of any planned purchase to you in certain other public officials at least 120 days prior to purchase

[Falco]: This letter is intended to serve as such notice.

[Falco]: The property is located at 99 Riverside Avenue, Medford.

[Falco]: This unique parcel is a portion of land owned by BNYH Medford LLC along the banks of the Mystic River.

[Falco]: It shall be part of a bikeway and pedestrian pathway to be known as the Clippership Connector.

[Falco]: The property under consideration contains 5,220,000 square feet of land.

[Falco]: The locus map exhibited exhibit A.

[Falco]: shows a property in which we are interested.

[Falco]: The current owner use of the property is undeveloped open space.

[Falco]: If acquired by the state, DCR will retain the property easement for the purpose of stated above.

[Falco]: The applicable regulations require that an agency proposal to acquire property to be made public in a local forum.

[Falco]: To comply with this requirement, we ask that the Board of Selectmen

[Falco]: Announce the Commonwealth is considering the acquisition for the above stated purpose at its next regularly scheduled meeting and document the announcement of the enclosed form and return it to us in a self-addressed envelope enclosed for your convenience.

[Falco]: Should you have any questions regarding this matter, kindly contact Sean Getchell, Director of Government Affairs at 617-626-4991.

[Falco]: For your information, the DCR has sent similar notices to Representative Paul J. Donato, Senator Patricia Jalen, and the Metropolitan Area Planning Council.

[Falco]: Thank you very much.

[Falco]: Very truly yours, Arthur C. George, Assistant General Counsel.

[Falco]: So, just wanted to bring that to everybody's attention.

[Falco]: You're very welcome, Councilor Caraviello.

[Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: Offered by Councilor Marks, be it resolved at 2-0-040, be it resolved that a moment of silence be held for long-time resident Gerard Edouard on his recent passing.

[Falco]: Chancellor Marks.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Falco]: At this time, I would ask everyone to please rise for a brief moment of silence, thoughts and prayers with their families.

[Falco]: We have one more paper, Councilman.

[Falco]: Vice President Caraviello.

[Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Falco]: Of course, I'm in full support of this.

[Falco]: This is something that many residents have called about.

[Falco]: I think our goal is always to try to get more people involved in government in what's happening throughout the community.

[Falco]: And a way of doing this is to actually have meetings that make sense for the majority of the population.

[Falco]: Having meetings during the afternoon does not work for a lot of people.

[Falco]: And for many people throughout our community, you know, having meetings at 2 o'clock in the afternoon.

[Falco]: I think Councilor Marks, you mentioned it earlier with regard to the Verizon hearing.

[Falco]: I mean, that doesn't make sense.

[Falco]: It doesn't really make sense to have meetings at 2 o'clock in the afternoon if you want the general public to attend.

[Falco]: Most people are working.

[Falco]: They're picking up their kids from school.

[Falco]: They might have other appointments as well.

[Falco]: So I think, you know, having meetings anytime after 6 p.m.

[Falco]: makes complete sense.

[Falco]: Most of the general public can come to meetings at that time, and I think it's something that we need to make sure that this happens, to make sure that, you know, in the sense of transparency, in the sense of getting people involved in what's going on throughout the community, I think it'd be in the benefit of most people throughout this community, and the city in general, that we make sure that these meetings are held, you know, anytime after 6 p.m.

[Falco]: So I thank you very much.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight, as well.

[Falco]: All those in favor?

[Falco]: The motion passes.

[Falco]: Reports of committees, 2-0-017, Committee of the Whole meeting report, Wednesday, January 15, 2020 at 6 p.m.

[Falco]: in room 207, Council Office, Medford City Hall.

[Falco]: We met last Wednesday as a Committee of the Whole to discuss the priorities for the Medford City Council for this year, 2020.

[Falco]: We went through

[Falco]: A number of items ranging from the basic city services and how to actually provide them more efficiently.

[Falco]: We talked a little bit about headcount in each of the departments and hopefully increasing headcount.

[Falco]: We talked about meetings, regular meetings with department heads ahead of the budget season.

[Falco]: So if we have any questions we can ask them.

[Falco]: before the budget is crafted for the upcoming year.

[Falco]: We talked a little bit about strategic about a strategic master plan.

[Falco]: We talked about meeting with the mayor and we will I'll be scheduling that soon.

[Falco]: I'll be reaching out to the mayor's office to discuss our priorities with her so we can invite her to committee the whole meeting.

[Falco]: We talked about housing, inclusionary zoning,

[Falco]: We talked about the traffic commission meetings as well.

[Falco]: We also talked about

[Falco]: Let's see we talked about actually the city council Having a legal services line item so that the council can have its own legal counsel of various priorities including city ordinances in other Items, and I think that's something that the council agrees on would go a long way Especially the number of ordinances that we're trying to write at this point in time We talked about revenue priorities.

[Falco]: We talked about various ordinances that we have to work on in the upcoming year and

[Falco]: We talked about citywide technology, pedestrian safety.

[Falco]: We talked about the behavioral health commission.

[Falco]: We talked about breweries ordinance, food trucks.

[Falco]: Talked a little bit about taxes.

[Falco]: So the meeting wasn't limited to that, but we talked about a far-ranging number of issues and priorities for the upcoming year.

[Falco]: And to say the least, it will be a very busy year, a lot of meetings, but I think there's a lot of work that needs to get done, and I know we can get it done together.

[Falco]: So on the motion of Councilor Caraviello to approve the committee report, seconded by Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: If I could?

[Falco]: Yes, of course.

[Falco]: Karl Marx.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Falco]: I'm looking to, like I said, schedule a meeting soon with the mayor, and have the mayor come to Committee of the Whole so we can all talk together, and then we'll hopefully schedule some department head meetings after that to get working on those issues.

[Falco]: At this point, I recognize Councilor Caraviello.

[Falco]: Not just spreadsheets.

[Falco]: Back a few years ago, when I first got on the council, that was one of my big priorities, was getting a budget with a narrative.

[Falco]: Correct, so we're hoping to continue forward with that, and I would think and hope that the mayor would as well.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Yes I do, Mr. President, thank you.

[Falco]: We had a subcommittee on zoning on February 6th, 2018 at 6 p.m.

[Falco]: And the members of this subcommittee are myself, Councilor Knight, and Councilor Lungo-Koehn.

[Falco]: The purpose of the meeting was to review all papers assigned to the subcommittee of zoning and ordinances and to review zoning.

[Falco]: So at the beginning of this term, Mr. President, you decided to split these former zoning and ordinance subcommittee to two separate subcommittees.

[Falco]: One was zoning and one is ordinance.

[Falco]: So what we did is we actually just went through the papers that were in committee and we moved

[Falco]: Papers 16555, 16660, 16705, 17542, 17094, 17321, and 17320 to the subcommittee on ordinances.

[Falco]: Papers 16-359, 16-338.

[Falco]: 16, 6, 2, 6, and 16, 6, 6, 6 are staying in the zoning subcommittee.

[Falco]: Uh, we also, I talked about, um, inclusionary housing and mixed use housing and the committee members are going to be doing some research, uh, or have been doing research over the past couple of weeks, uh, to, um, to present, uh, at a meeting, um, next week.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent.

[Falco]: Thank you, Chief Sacco.

[Falco]: I find everything to be very alarming.

[Falco]: As a father of three kids in the Medford Public Schools, I always feel that my kids are safe.

[Falco]: And now I see something like this today, and I feel they're safe, but I have concerns.

[Falco]: And I think they're very valid concerns.

[Falco]: You know, as far as, you know, when we notify police about an incident like this, do we have a clear policy as to when?

[Falco]: I mean, to me, there should be a clear, you know, I watch the commercials, I hear it on the radio, I see it on TV.

[Falco]: See something, say something.

[Falco]: I tell my kids that.

[Falco]: You know, and I think it's a good theory to go by.

[Falco]: Because I think, you know, we need to,

[Falco]: keep law enforcement active and engaged in what's going on.

[Falco]: To me, this is a clear case where see something, say something should have been the appropriate choice.

[Falco]: Do we have a clear policy that says in this situation, there's some sort of ammunition and I'm no gun expert, but there's some sort of weapon that we contact the police.

[Falco]: Yes, I have.

[Falco]: What I would like to see is I would like to see the school committee work on a clear policy.

[Falco]: But I think the parents as well, because if you're going to notify the school committee, that's going to go out to the general public.

[Falco]: So the general public should hear from our school leader, the superintendent saying, this is a concern.

[Falco]: This is what's been found.

[Falco]: This is what we think is happening.

[Falco]: I mean, getting input from the chief as well.

[Falco]: I think, you know,

[Falco]: You know, I understand that there are probably certain issues that are minor, that maybe not everyone needs to know about, if there's a fight in the playground or something like that.

[Falco]: But something like this, where there's a piece of ammunition that's found, you know, within the school building, that that's a concern.

[Falco]: And that's a concern that many people have here tonight.

[Falco]: There's many people that are watching at home that have this concern.

[Falco]: And I know all of us behind this rail have the same concern.

[Falco]: Mr. Superintendent, I would honestly like to see you, the police chief Sacco, and the

[Falco]: the mayor and the school committee come together and formulate a policy as to, you know, when, you know, to actually put a policy in place, when should the police be contacted about an issue like this?

[Falco]: Because I think there needs to be a clear definition, in my opinion.

[Falco]: I mean, I'd like to see that.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Now, the Thursday night meeting, which I know I've received a ton of calls about, I believe that's going to be at the high school.

[Falco]: I would respectfully ask that that be held here.

[Falco]: I think it's, you know,

[Falco]: from being a former school committee member, having meetings at the high school, the acoustics are really, they're not great.

[Falco]: I think you, my guess is you're gonna have a lot of people at this meeting.

[Falco]: I think that it's better situated to be here.

[Falco]: You have microphones, you have, people will be able to actually hear the dialogue.

[Falco]: This is an important topic.

[Falco]: It's an important issue that people wanna know about.

[Falco]: They wanna know what happened, when it happened.

[Falco]: They wanna see a timeline.

[Falco]: I think that if you try to have a meeting like that in a library or the superintendent's conference room,

[Falco]: I really think that's probably not the best way to go.

[Falco]: I think having it here at Chambers is the best venue to have the meeting.

[Falco]: I think it seats more people.

[Falco]: And I think, like I said, the acoustics are much better.

[Falco]: I've been to budget meetings up at the library.

[Falco]: And if you're sitting in the back, you really have no idea what's going on up at the front, just because the acoustics are not great.

[Falco]: Yeah.
