[Falco]: As many of you know, I've been on board with municipal aggregation since day one.

[Falco]: I think it's a good, in my eyes, I think it's a good

[Falco]: a good plan, I think it's a good program.

[Falco]: And I, I too think that, you know, we're at the point now where, you know, I think we've heard from, you know, you know, at the last meeting we heard from someone from the energy department in Melrose just to get a different perspective.

[Falco]: And I think, I thought that was a very good presentation.

[Falco]: She did a great job and it was good to see how another city handled the communication and how they worked through the project.

[Falco]: And she had all kinds of samples of communications that they sent out.

[Falco]: But I, in fact, I also agree with the Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: I think we need to take a vote on this to see where we're going.

[Falco]: You know, I mean, I would, I guess I feel the same way.

[Falco]: I mean, I don't want to put resources working on something that might not even pass.

[Falco]: So, you know, I think, you know, it's time.

[Falco]: This has been, I think municipal aggregation has been with us for over a year now.

[Falco]: We've had many meetings, Committee of the Wholes, we've taken one vote, it went down, and it's come back, but I think we need to take a vote on this.

[Falco]: And I know, I think the paper is still in committee, or actually it's in Committee of the Wholes, so I think we probably need to vote that out at some point.

[Falco]: But I think that, in my opinion, I really don't, I think a lot of our

[Falco]: departments to stretch with regard to resources.

[Falco]: And I would, I really don't, um, like the fact that we're going to put a resource towards building this list if this might not even pass.

[Falco]: So, um, I, I, uh, agree with my colleague, uh, councilor Knight on this issue.

[Falco]: So thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: I also want to go on the record of supporting this.

[Falco]: Um, I take a look at the Brooks Estate and I take a look at the, uh, the money that, um, I mean, I look at it as,

[Falco]: If we appropriate this money tonight, to me, to me, this is an investment.

[Falco]: It's an investment in the Brooks estate.

[Falco]: It's an investment in our community.

[Falco]: I mean, there are other cities and towns that would really love to have a property like this.

[Falco]: Uh, like council and I said, 50 acres of, uh, open space.

[Falco]: I think it's a great opportunity.

[Falco]: Um, and I think that's something that we need to look at, but I think we need to, I think we need to embrace this.

[Falco]: I mean, I think that this is a,

[Falco]: This is a historical site.

[Falco]: I think there's a lot of opportunity here, the potential to actually bring in revenue.

[Falco]: So this is something that I do support as well.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: had the opportunity last week to attend the monthly community police meeting down at the Medford Police Station.

[Falco]: And once again, they had a nice crowd, probably about 25, 30 people.

[Falco]: And there was about 10 people from Fern Road that attended.

[Falco]: And they had major issues on that road with regard to traffic and speeding.

[Falco]: And at the end of Fern Road is the intersection of Fulton Spring Road and Vista Ave and the other side of Fern Road.

[Falco]: It's a four-way stop.

[Falco]: And it's also a location for a bus stop.

[Falco]: And the traffic in that area in the morning and in the evening is really, really bad with people flying through the stop sign and then progressing down towards the Felsway.

[Falco]: And the speeding is really out of control.

[Falco]: And the residents that were there that night expressed that.

[Falco]: And so I just wanted to ask for increased patrols on that street.

[Falco]: And if we could add a temporary speed bump to that street as well.

[Falco]: It came up that night.

[Falco]: Chief Sacco said he had no problems with it.

[Falco]: He was in favor of it.

[Falco]: And since I wrote this resolution, I've also talked to Brian Kearns as well.

[Falco]: And I believe Sergeant Hartnett was going up to look at the situation today.

[Falco]: So that's a little bit of an update.

[Falco]: But there are actually a couple of residents here that would like to speak on this issue.

[Falco]: I think they are so It's a temporary speed bump that they pull up in the winter because of the plows they can't keep it down year-round but It's definitely I think Something that would help in this situation.

[Falco]: I mean we would I took a walk I live right around the corner and I took a walk down the street and met with the residents on Saturday and

[Falco]: And it's interesting, there's a pothole in the street.

[Falco]: And some of them are like, don't fill the pothole because it slows down the traffic.

[Falco]: And that really shouldn't be the solution.

[Falco]: We should make sure that we fill the pothole and slow down traffic.

[Falco]: So we're hoping that putting in that temporary speed bump would help slow down the traffic, help drivers realize that, you know what, this is a busy neighborhood.

[Falco]: There's a lot of people, a lot of cars.

[Falco]: This is a school bus stop close by.

[Falco]: People have to drive safely.

[Falco]: And so I basically would ask a move for approval at this point.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: And thank you for your support.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you very much.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: I'd like to thank Councilor Longo-Kerr for bringing this resolution forward.

[Falco]: This is an issue that I get calls about all the time.

[Falco]: And like you said, it doesn't matter really what part of the city you live in.

[Falco]: It impacts everyone.

[Falco]: And it's unfortunate.

[Falco]: I was at that meeting about a month ago that they had right here at City Hall, and the place was packed.

[Falco]: And it really does impact the quality of life.

[Falco]: We should be doing everything we can to combat this.

[Falco]: I know I've actually been communicating to people in the community to call the Massport line and to log complaints online.

[Falco]: And you're right.

[Falco]: And one of the things that they did mention that night was all of the planes, basically, when they take off, they come

[Falco]: basically right down Riverside Ave, right over the Andrews.

[Falco]: So it does sound like probably a good place to have the beacon.

[Falco]: But the thing to really keep in mind here is that that night at the meeting, what they mentioned is this problem is really only going to get worse because of the reconfiguration of, I think it was Terminal E, and there's going to be over the next, I think, five years, there's going to be more carriers leaving it at off-peak times.

[Falco]: So this problem, I know people say, well, once they repair that runway,

[Falco]: You know, it's going to get better.

[Falco]: Maybe it will get better for the short term, but for the long term, this is a problem that's going to impact us for a very long time.

[Falco]: So we really need to make sure that we stay on top of this.

[Falco]: Thank you for bringing this forward.

[Falco]: And people really need to continue to make sure that they call the Massport noise line and to log their complaints online as well.

[Falco]: It does have an impact.

[Falco]: You can see in Milton, the city of Milton, that it had an impact.

[Falco]: thousands and thousands of more complaints than we do.

[Falco]: So people really need to get out, voice their opinion, and let Massport know that this is a problem, and it does impact the quality of life.

[Falco]: So I'd just like to thank you for bringing this forward, and I second the motion.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: I'd like to thank my council colleagues for bringing this forward.

[Falco]: I think this is a very important issue.

[Falco]: Um, and you're right, it's a very important piece of property and there are a number of, um, groups that could use this as a home in the future.

[Falco]: The arts, recreation, you name it.

[Falco]: Um, it's, it's a, it's,

[Falco]: It's a prime opportunity.

[Falco]: The property has not been in the control of the city for many years.

[Falco]: And we should really see firsthand, I think, the condition of the building and what we're getting back.

[Falco]: But if that's not going to happen, I'd like to amend the paper, if you don't mind.

[Falco]: that we get a report back from the building department that gives us basically a report back to us about the overall condition of the building, you know, with regard to, you know, heating or windows, roofing, I mean, anything like that.

[Falco]: I mean, this is something that we need to consider.

[Falco]: We should know about this.

[Falco]: I mean, these are very important matters.

[Falco]: I mean, anytime you have a building like this, that's,

[Falco]: That's part of your city.

[Falco]: And you really need to know and keep an eye on the maintenance, the preventive maintenance, what kind of money has been spent or is going to be spent, what kind of money it's going to take to bring this back online.

[Falco]: I mean, I assume it's probably ready to go, because it was functioning not too long ago.

[Falco]: But I really think we should, as a council and as a city, know what we're getting back from Bridgewell.

[Falco]: So if I could amend the paper to include that, I'd greatly appreciate it.

[Falco]: And I second that resolution.

[Falco]: Thank you.

[Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: I just wanted to thank Councilor Knight for bringing this forward.

[Falco]: This issue actually came up during a police community meeting a couple of months ago.

[Falco]: And talking to the members of the police department, you know, they talk a lot about how surrounding communities have

[Falco]: cameras in a lot of different intersections and whatnot, and how it's actually been key in solving crimes and whatnot.

[Falco]: And our city really does not have a lot of cameras, or I don't think any cameras, really, at any of our public places.

[Falco]: But if you wouldn't mind.

[Falco]: amending the resolution.

[Falco]: Greatly appreciate it.

[Falco]: And I second the motion.

[Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: And the reason why I amended it was because it did come up at a police community meeting and the police officers that I talked to that were in the room and the detectives, they had mentioned that all the surrounding communities had these cameras in the very useful, uh, in, you know, especially if a crime has happened, you know, they can always consult the cameras or if there's a car chase or something like that, or if something happens in Somerville, uh, you know, and they come through Medford, you know, this, you know, they can actually see things on tape.

[Falco]: Um, a lot of times, you know,

[Falco]: When it comes to Medford, you can't see anything because there's no cameras.

[Falco]: But they have them in all surrounding areas, surrounding cities and towns.

[Falco]: And they've been extremely helpful.

[Falco]: I know that things have happened in Medford where, you know, they've

[Falco]: The people that have broken the law have gone down to cities and towns, and they've consulted these cameras.

[Falco]: And it's really helped out a lot from what I was told that night.

[Falco]: And they're all accessible right through the phone if they need to look at a camera right away.

[Falco]: So I think it's a good way to possibly help to solve crimes.

[Falco]: But I don't think it's a way to go out to see if someone's speeding or something like that.

[Falco]: That's not the purpose.

[Falco]: It would be to actually just to try to, after crime has been committed, to actually

[Falco]: go back and look at a tape and say, OK, wait a second.

[Falco]: They actually came running down Mr. Gabel, whatever it may be.

[Falco]: But I think it's a good tool to have.

[Falco]: And I think it's a really inexpensive option.

[Falco]: I mean, cameras are pretty inexpensive these days.

[Falco]: And so I don't think it's something that could be very beneficial to the police department in solving crimes.

[Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Falco]: The purpose of the meeting was to view and discuss government legislative management software, which includes the agenda, minutes, and video streaming the meeting.

[Falco]: It was a good meeting.

[Falco]: We actually asked a lot of questions.

[Falco]: We got a nice presentation from Acela,

[Falco]: They have experience with, we have surrounding communities that also use this type of product.

[Falco]: They use it in Somerville, Melrose, I believe maybe Cambridge as well.

[Falco]: It's basically a product that will bring a lot of transparency to the process and the way we view agendas and minutes here at City Hall.

[Falco]: The public would have all the information at their fingertips.

[Falco]: with regard to researching information if they wanted to.

[Falco]: So it's a very powerful tool.

[Falco]: I think it's great with regard to transparency.

[Falco]: All the reports that we get back here, they will be able to access on their phones or laptops or iPads or whatever it may be.

[Falco]: But I think it's a great tool with regard to transparency.

[Falco]: Video streaming is a powerful tool as well.

[Falco]: It would allow us to actually

[Falco]: Filmer meetings, the city council office, if we choose.

[Falco]: And it's also great because we have a lot of boards and commissions in our community.

[Falco]: And I think a lot of people really don't know what the boards and commissions do.

[Falco]: But with the agenda minutes meeting software, it would allow all of the boards and commission minutes, agenda minutes and software, all be online.

[Falco]: So really, it benefits the community in many ways with regard to transparency.

[Falco]: they'd actually be able to view and see the meetings whenever they want.

[Falco]: So everything would be online.

[Falco]: It was a great meeting, went really well, great questions.

[Falco]: So that's basically a brief synopsis.
